When he dies, he might leave no more trace than a stone thrown into a river. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. But maybe his way of life and his strong and kind character will influence others, and people will realize he was special. Then, it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know about his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book will be helpful to those who write about my friend. I don't claim that the conversations I wrote are exact. I never took notes, but I remember well what matters to me. I have written these conversations in my own words, but I believe they are true to what was said. I mentioned earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have added some speeches to make the story more lively, like historians do. I want my book to be interesting to read. The smart reader will know where I have used this trick and can choose to ignore it. Another reason I am worried about writing this book is that the people I write about are from another culture. It is hard to truly know people from a different country. People are shaped by where they were born, the games they played, the food they ate, and the schools they went to. You can't really know these things unless you have lived them. Because of this, it is hard to make foreign characters believable in a book. I usually write about people from my own country, and if I write about others in short stories, it's because you can describe them briefly. In this book, I don't pretend my characters see themselves as I describe them; they are seen through my eyes.

**Poetry Recitals**
Throughout history, the world of literature often seems confusing to those living in it. It is only later that people can see the patterns and importance of different works. Today, poetry is especially complex with many different styles and opinions about how poetry should be written, shared, and taught. There is a debate between two main groups: serious 'literary' poets who write poems to be read on paper, and 'popular' poets who prefer performing their poems to an audience. 
This division is not strict, and public poetry readings have become more common in the last twenty years. These readings happen in various places like small town halls, schools, colleges, and arts festivals. Poets are often invited to read and talk to audiences. For 'pop' poets, who write their poems to be performed, these events are beneficial. Their poems are usually simple and easy to understand when heard once. However, when read on paper, their weaknesses might be more noticeable.
On the other hand, poets who focus on the craft of poetry, trying to include deep emotions, thoughts, and creativity in their work, might not be fully appreciated by audiences hearing their poems for the first time. The risk is that these poets might choose to read only their simpler works to connect quickly with the audience, which might not show their true style.
Listening to poetry readings is not the same as reading poetry on paper, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing poets read their work can help listeners understand the emphasis and rhythm of the poems. It is helpful if the audience can follow along with the text or know the poems beforehand.
The main reason for popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is to help people enjoy poetry and see it as something fun, not just for a special group of people.

**Oral History**
Historians are using more oral evidence, but it has challenges. When someone tells their story, it is not always a clear picture of the past. During an interview, both the historian and the person being interviewed affect each other. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to talk about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final story is influenced by the historian's background and how they understand history. Historians must realize they help create new evidence. Also, the person telling their story is not directly connected to the past. Their memories might be mixed with things they heard from other places, like the media. They might remember the past as better than it was or feel upset about things that happened later. The emotions in their story can make it seem true, but these feelings might come from later events, not the time they are talking about.
**Animal Science**
There are two main ways to study animal science: looking at how the body works and looking at the whole animal. Physiologists study how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create behavior. People who study the whole animal look at the animal's behavior and what affects it. Within this group, psychologists and ethologists are different. Psychologists usually work in labs with animals like rats and pigeons to see how they learn. Ethologists study animals in the wild to see their natural behavior. These two groups are starting to work together more. Physiologists think their methods are very important, but even if we knew everything about how nerves work, we still need to study behavior as a whole. Behavior has its own patterns that we need to understand. Trying to explain a bird building a nest by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.
**The Social Sciences**
When students start studying social sciences, they have to do two things at once. They need to learn about the subject and also understand how to study it. This means knowing the information in textbooks and also learning how this information is found and organized. These two parts are connected. We all know about social life from our daily experiences, so we might think social sciences are just common sense. But, as textbooks show, each social science looks at people in society in a special way. Each one has its own methods and ideas. These basic ideas are what make social sciences different from common sense and from each other.
**Classical Architecture**
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used some Greek words for these ideas, which probably came from an earlier Greek writer. Vitruvius did not include utility and function in his main definition, but he did talk about the best ways to build for different purposes. At the start, the focus was on architecture as an art. The origins of classical architecture are complex. Before the classical style, there were simple huts in Greece and Italy. These huts did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards, but they still influenced later architecture. Even if a classical temple looks fancy, it is basically a simple, single-roomed hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, near the railway line and gasworks, even jumping a small bridge with all four wheels off the ground, which was her only mistake. Chen, however, found it amusing when he discovered what Lily had been doing. He was impressed and said, "So you can really drive it then, Lily? Well done!" Mui thought men were strange because Chen should have been upset, but instead, he was excited and started planning a trip with Lily. They decided to go on a Monday at the beginning of next month, as it was the quietest day of the week. They planned to leave early in the morning and return by midday to avoid losing customers. Meanwhile, Lily would practice driving around the allotments. Mui, despite her doubts, bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.
On the day of the trip, they left the house and, within an hour, were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove perfectly, and even Mui, who was ready to give directions from the back seat, had to admit it. Lily overtook a few slow vehicles with great skill, and Chen even applauded her. After passing through the gasworks of a seaside town, they drove along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a small street with many empty parking spaces. She wasn't sure about the road markings, so she preferred to pay a parking fee rather than risk getting towed or fined. Lily locked all the van doors carefully. Chen joked, "Don't worry, no one will want that heap of tin," which made the sisters upset. Lily accused him of being ungrateful, and Mui told him he was too easily fooled by appearances. Surprised, Chen took their son, Man Kee, to look at the sea. He held Man Kee on the railing and thought about his son's future. Chen wanted Man Kee to have a good education and own many restaurants one day.
The sight of the sea made Chen feel thoughtful. He saw a ship in the distance and used a telescope to look at it. He imagined it as a special ship that would take them back home one day. Chen lifted Man Kee to the telescope and said, "Do you see the ship, Son? It is a special little ship for people like us. It will take you to your homeland, which you have never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui joined them, and Chen let Lily look through the telescope. But by then, the ship was gone, and all Lily could see were seagulls flying.

'THE WELL I read somewhere that if you look from a deep hole, you can see stars during the day. I convinced you to help me try this. You watched as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't think about how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not be strong enough. You held the handle, but when I pushed the bucket off the well's edge, I fell. You screamed and tried to stop the handle, but then you let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. I didn't realize then that I had kind of succeeded in my plan. I saw strange lights, like stars. Later, I thought about how in cartoons, characters see stars when they get hit. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what Mother would say. You called down to ask if I was okay. I was about to shout back, but you called again, sounding scared, and I stayed quiet. I watched you through my eyelashes. You ran to get help. I waited a bit, then climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows. I heard voices from the castle. Mother and Father came with you and Arthur. Mother was upset, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked pale and shocked. I felt excited but then saw the wet spots I left on the ground. I was scared they would see them. Mother was screaming, and I felt guilty. I wanted revenge on you, but now it was serious. I realized I needed a plan. I came out of hiding, pretending to be weak. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled out. I thought they believed me until Father asked me to repeat the story. I added that the tunnel collapsed after me, so no one could check. Father looked at me like he saw through my lie. He told me not to be ridiculous and walked away. Arthur looked at me sadly, knowing I was lying. His look made me feel ashamed, like my father's words. I realized they both saw through my lie, and it made me think about how I would see things when I grew up.'

**Moving Day**
Susan, who is now a widow, has to leave her family home because her children are grown up. She noticed the moving van had "Removers of Distinction" written on it. Fred, the removal man, was carefully packing everything in the house, while his team was not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house that looked over a small harbor. She remembered the years spent there with her children growing up.
When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, asked how they would bring the house home. Now, Robert was helping with the move, making sure Susan didn't mention the piano. Her daughter Francesca was also there, insisting she was the only one careful enough to handle their Steinway piano.
Fred, the removal man, noticed Susan wasn't crying. He said many people cry when they see their things being taken away, but they feel better once they reach the new place. Susan could understand why. She remembered when they first moved in, the piano was a big problem. It got stuck on the stairs, and they had to remove the banister rails to get it in. Her late husband, Peter, solved the problem by hiring a builder to take out a window and using a crane to bring the piano inside.
Now, Susan was worried about moving the piano out. She sat on the stairs, thinking about the past. Fred asked if she was okay, and she moved aside as they prepared to move the piano. Robert and Francesca watched from the hallway. Susan felt like crying because moving made her realize how much everything mattered to her.
Finally, the piano was moved safely out of the house. Robert started laughing, and soon all three of them were laughing together, relieved that the move was over. As they walked down the path for the last time, Susan's tears were tears of laughter.

**Online Book Reviews: Fun for Everyone?**
When the Internet started, one big idea was that anyone could share their thoughts online. In the beginning, you needed some technical skills to do this. But there was one area that became open to everyone: book reviews. 
Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, allowed anyone to write a book review. This meant people could share their opinions about books and give them up to five stars. Each book had its own page, and new reviews appeared automatically. This helped Amazon fill its site with free reviews, and buyers could see what other readers thought, not just what publishers or professional critics said.
Other online bookstores did the same, but Amazon was the biggest, with over 80% of the market. Because of this, Amazon had the most reviews and also some problems. Many reviews were submitted every day, so it was hard to check them all. Amazon had a team to make sure reviews followed their rules. For example, reviews couldn't be just one word, attack the author, or spoil the ending. But since reviewers were anonymous, some fake reviews slipped through.
Some authors wrote fake positive reviews for their own books. For example, Lev Grossman wrote good reviews for his book after getting bad ones. He was caught when he admitted it in an article, and the fake reviews were removed. Authors could also comment on their books through a special link, but Amazon didn't always check if the comments were really from the author. 
Sometimes, readers used reviews to express anger. For example, when James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team came out, people mentioned in the book wrote angry reviews on Amazon. These reviews disappeared after a few days.
Despite these issues, Amazon liked that people spent time writing reviews because it was good for business. They watched popular books closely to make sure reviews followed the rules. Funny reviews were more common on less popular books. For example, a children's book called "The Story about Ping" inspired jokes because "ping" is also a computer term.
Most reviews on Amazon were serious and gave a good idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books could be boring. But with everyone able to write reviews, it became a more interesting and fair process.

**Art in Modern Times**
In the last 200 years, people often think that artists must be different from others. We like art that is unique, new, and sometimes shocking. We admire artists whose work was not liked 100 years ago. But with today's art, we sometimes feel unsure and think an artist has gone too far. The media often tells us what to think, and we agree because we expect art to be new and confusing. We forget that modern art also has old themes and methods. We want artists to be special and different from us, with talents that break the rules. In the past, people asked artists to create art for specific reasons, and it was part of everyday life. Now, we let artists do what they want and get upset if they try to be like everyone else.
**Picture This**
Let me describe a situation and ask an important question. An artist picks a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about different kinds of pictures and says, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." The artist asks someone to make a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter writes the text on the canvas in simple black letters. My question is: Is this a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26th, there is an unspoken rule that once a painter finds success in one style, they should stick to it. Collectors want artists to keep doing the same thing, and trying something new can upset them. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, have changed styles and succeeded. Eric Rimmington is another artist trying something new. He is known for still life paintings but now paints the London Underground. He has always been interested in railways and has made 40 paintings and drawings of the underground world for his new show, "Underground Encounters."
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with a few books. The villagers joke that only a sick person would come to such a remote place to heal. I am alone except for an old woman who comes to clean the house. I am neither happy nor unhappy, just thinking about memories. I talked about how art seems useless but did not mention its comforts. The comfort in art is that it allows us to change reality and see its true meaning. Our everyday actions hide the real beauty of life. For artists, art is a way to deal with what hurts us in life, not to avoid it, but to understand it better. Otherwise, why do we hurt each other?

Title: Family Business
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father and my brother Maurice had just picked me up from my fancy girls' school. I had won the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my exams. My father had talked with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, though I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. He usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you might get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I said, trying to act brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, and I knew he was about to confront me, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can understand things quickly, you talk well, and you like performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV dramas."
"Be that as it may," he said, "I feel your heart's not going to be in the family business now. You'll go to Oxford, and after that, I can't see you wanting it."
Like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw other jobs I could do and wanted to explore them. But I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was usually right about these things, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant."
My mother wasn't around to help - she died when I was young, and my father raised Maurice and me. Maurice was two years younger, and I got used to taking care of him. It wasn't hard. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, nice schools, clothes, parties, theatres, and operas. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was always lively.
"I tell you what," my father said. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me."
"OK," I said, relieved to avoid making immediate decisions and to avoid my father's sulks if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.
So it happened. In my last term at school and during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on safer tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a little house, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label for my final exams.
In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew if I focused, he might be right. I felt confident and ready.
But my father told me he needed me for one last important job for the family business, and it would be worth my while.
"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams soon, and I need to focus on them. It's really important that I do well."
I could tell my father didn't understand the pressure I felt, or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him. He would see a refusal as a betrayal.
As he explained the job, I saw how focused and talented my father was. He was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with money, which wasn't ideal. At first, it seemed like a good idea because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois had returned to her job at an advertising agency after having twins. She even got a raise, making her salary thirty-five thousand. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found these things in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted a better address for their social status. 
To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him unhappy. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he was treated well after a long day. But times had changed, and Lois made it clear that her career was as important as Simon's. They needed both their salaries to maintain their lifestyle.
Now, their situation was at risk because of Venetia, who was very upset. She accused Simon of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors in a case four years ago and that Cartwright had given shares to Simon's fiancée. Simon denied it, but his denial didn't sound convincing, even to himself. He felt guilty and remembered feeling scared of punishment as a child. Venetia didn't believe him, and he worried about what she might do. If the rumor spread, his career could be ruined.

I chose to live here because I thought I could be anonymous among people who didn't care if their rented houses were falling apart or if their gardens were overgrown. But I was wrong. People in the shops start to recognize you, even if you don't feel like you're living a real life. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside to forget about summer, but tonight I'm watching birds fly between the trees and roofs. I cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched from the plants. It's a small London garden where plants grow tall to survive. 
My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She's written several unpublished books, and as an English teacher, I sometimes have to pretend to like them. I have her latest book now. 'How's the work going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask you about your work all the time,' she replies. Then she says, 'I'll bring something to drink.' I don't want Jaz in the garden, and I realize it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 'You're on holiday now,' she says, sitting in the chair. 'I should've been a teacher - writers don't get holidays. They say those who can, do, and those who can't, teach.' And some can't do either. 'What are your plans for the holidays?' she asks. 
I feel worried about the school year ending. Empty days, hot streets, and loneliness in the park. 'I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask, feeling nervous. 'Of course,' Jaz says, knowing she will be around. 'Where will you stay?' she asks. 'With my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun,' I lie. 'Going back to your roots. What do you think of my book?' Jaz asks about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven't finished reading. I like the title and tell her. I decide to be honest. 'Try writing about nice people for a change,' I suggest. 'Teachers!' Jaz replies like a student upset about a bad grade. 'I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,' I say. 'Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann,' Jaz says. 
I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes, reading on the train. When we go inside, my kitchen feels calm. Then I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking and saying, 'I've had my moments.' We almost died laughing.

**Heritage**
Heritage is important because it helps people feel connected to the past. We often know about our personal heritage, like who our grandparents were and stories about their lives. But we also need to learn about our wider past to understand our future. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us feel part of history. Just like we inherit genes, we also inherit culture from past generations. Even if there are parts of our national heritage we don't like, it is still ours, and it helps us feel connected. Heritage teaches us a lot and is important for our well-being. It affects everything from customs to things we use every day. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories from our ancestors. But now, because of changes in society, many of these stories are lost. Instead, places and buildings help us remember the past. It is important to keep and restore these links to honor our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I started writing a novel called "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became important. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the Fens, chose to write about it. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and empty, a good setting for my story. But I learned that the Fens are not just flat and empty. They are as English as any other place but also very unique and mysterious. Many English people find the Fens foreign, even though other unique areas in Britain are part of the nation's culture. The Fens are both empty and full, both farmed and wild, and both open and mysterious. While writing my novel, I didn't visit many places in the Fens. As a fiction writer, I like to imagine worlds rather than rely on facts. The Fens are not just a place but also a state of mind.
**Museums**
Museums should make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels. Now, displays should be interesting and use creative techniques to capture visitors' attention. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can provide boxes of objects for teachers to use in class or for helping elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real items, not copies. They show things that were used and had meaning in the past. This is what makes them different from heritage centers and theme parks. Museums that create exciting displays and programs will find that people interested in virtual history will also want to see the real things that only museums can offer.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to preserve things is not new, but changes in our towns happen quickly and affect us all. Some people become strong preservationists, while others think about the future of towns. People who have lived through big events like world wars may care more about preserving things because they value stability. If there is a need to preserve, planners should consider it. Change is not bad if we learn to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect changes in society, like our population, well-being, and needs.

**Einstein**
If you ask someone on the street to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is often used in ads for smart products like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he created theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that don't match everyday life. Einstein was part of a big change in science, which started modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to describe the universe better by studying matter and natural forces. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking basic ideas like time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, people believed in Isaac Newton's idea that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this by saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.
**Young Readers**
When we were kids, Lydia and I didn't trust books that won prizes because we thought they would be boring. Our mother didn't like this attitude, but our father would give us small amounts of money to encourage us to read these books. He would also give us better books as gifts, marking them with 'This Book is NOT Literature'. We called most of these 'boys' books', but sometimes we found good short stories and once, a famous book of poems.
**Language**
In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that the origin of human language is a secret and amazing thing. This mystery has led to many strange ideas. In 1928, Charles Caller said that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad, and people in dangerous places made desperate noises. Some words today might still have echoes of these sounds, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" or the Latin 'mors' meaning "death". Because of these odd ideas, many people avoided talking about language origins, thinking it was for crazy people. But now, the origin and evolution of language are important research areas. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and was important in power struggles. Sharing information was not its main purpose, even though philosopher John Locke thought language was a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews from a writer's point of view. Most reviews are written quickly and don't last long. They have deadlines and are usually short. Once published, they are only read for a short time, like a day or a week. People often think reviews are not very important. Many believe that writers do reviews because they need money or because they can't work on their main projects all the time. However, writing reviews is a skillful job. It's different to write a short review for a newspaper than a long one for an international journal. A reviewer must think about who will read the review, from casual readers to those very interested in the topic. Reviewers need to know a lot about different things and write clearly so people can understand and enjoy their writing. Reviewers often write other things besides reviews. For example, the American novelist John Updike writes reviews between writing his novels. He collects his reviews into books, even if they are short. Some people think only famous writers should keep their reviews, but others believe anyone can do it if they want to. I feel the same about my work. My main job is academic, and my serious books are academic too. In the English-speaking world, it's common for the same people to write both reviews and academic books. In the past, some academics didn't like professors writing reviews, but now it's more accepted. There is more reviewing work now, so many people can do it. I think this is good for readers because they know the reviewer understands the topic. It's also good for professors because it helps them stay connected to the real world. When professors talk to each other, they might use complex language, but when writing reviews, they need to be clear. In the end, reviewing is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and walked into the dark, quiet hallway. Even after three years, he sometimes felt a little unsure about owning the place when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the apartment, he would come home excited and curious, often as early as possible, wondering what the apartment had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or leaks, but the apartment always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as just another part of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated that he couldn't change it. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or a blinking light on the answering machine when he returned. He was glad the windows weren't broken and nothing was stolen, but he wondered what it would look like if something happened. From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to spending three or four quiet evenings at home each week. Once he left the busy office and started to feel like himself again on the bus ride home, he realized he didn't need to be alone, but he often forgot this when planning his social life. At his desk, he wanted to be alone with his things, but once he got home, he felt empty and waited for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him think that doing work he didn't like had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would read or listen to music at night, but he started to wonder why he did these things. His thoughts and feelings were unclear, and he couldn't find a connection. He remembered a time when he didn't feel so powerless, when he might have escaped if he had known his own worth. But he was eager to settle down with something, so he followed the first opportunity that came along. After university, he tried to make a plan for his future, but he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends and followed their paths, not thinking he could find a job that would make him happy. He went to one job interview and didn't think much about the job itself, which was an editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was just happy to have a nice conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't think about the long meetings he would have later. Neil offered him the job right away, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**
I was about to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I moved through ice-cream vans, many people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was going to the racecourse, and I tried to find a good spot. A part of the area was marked off for the race. It wasn't like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides of the track to watch the goats run. Keeping the goats in order was hard because goats are known to eat almost anything.
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I started to worry about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and there was nowhere to stop. We hadn't seen any villages or huts since the morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our torch to see the cliffs, but the torch batteries were dying. We put in new ones, but they didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley thought she saw a light, and we felt hopeful. But it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast water, but we couldn't see it. Time seemed to stop as we moved on.
**How to be Presentation Perfect**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and big shareholders. How can I get better at presentations and feel more confident? You are not alone. Presenting is a different skill from running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask colleagues to think of difficult questions the audience might ask. Start with something everyone agrees on and slowly build to your main point.

Some activities cannot be rushed. They need their own time. For example, if you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you add oil too quickly when making mayonnaise, it will not turn out right. If you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will get tighter. Our minds also work at different speeds. Some things we can do very quickly, like solving puzzles or doing math in our heads. But other things take longer, and if we rush them, they might not work well, like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.
We learn and think in different ways, and each way has its own speed. Sometimes we need to think fast, like when we are in danger. For example, when I was riding my motorbike and it skidded on a wet road, my body reacted quickly to keep me safe. This fast reaction is a kind of intelligence called 'wits'.
Then there is the kind of thinking where we solve problems by reasoning and logic. This is called 'intellect'. A mechanic fixing an engine or a student working on an assignment uses this kind of thinking. We call people who are good at this 'bright' or 'clever'.
There is also a slower way of thinking, which is more relaxed and dreamy. This is when we are daydreaming or just thinking about things without a clear purpose. It is important to let our minds wander sometimes. This slow thinking helps us understand complex situations better. It is like the story of the tortoise and the hare; we need both fast and slow thinking.
Recent studies show that slow thinking is good for understanding complicated problems. When we don't know what questions to ask or when the problem is too complex, slow thinking can help. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have long known the value of this kind of thinking. Scientists are now studying it too, and they find that our minds can solve difficult problems if we give them time.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I have been welcomed warmly in a friendly and well-supplied camp in a very remote place. There are about forty people here, including scientists, students, and weather experts. We all work together closely. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not for casual conversation. I miss the small details in conversations, and my phrasebook is not helpful at breakfast. This is not a big problem for me, but at first, it made me feel less confident. I was a bit nervous about mealtimes. I would hesitate, unsure which table to sit at, and worried about the silence when I spoke. I felt anxious, like when I first started school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think this sometimes makes me feel down because I am not as socially confident as I used to be.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was just a young writer, and he didn't pay much attention to me. He never forgot a face, though, and when we met again, he would shake my hand politely but didn't try to become friends. If I saw him at the opera with important people, he often pretended not to see me. But then I had a big success as a playwright, and Elliot started to like me more. One day, he invited me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After my success, I made many new friends and began to see him more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care much about the story or acting in his films. He cared more about the photography, music, and technical parts. For Hitchcock, it wasn't the message or acting that excited people. He believed that people reacted to the film itself, no matter where they were from. If a film was made well, people from Japan and India would react the same way. Hitchcock was very precise and logical. He was a genius who loved to hear the audience scream. He didn't focus on ideas or deep meanings. He focused on making films that had a strong emotional impact on the audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**
In the last 50 years, many things have changed in astronomy. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues. Telescopes were not very advanced, and there were few books about practical astronomy. Today, you can buy many different telescopes and equipment. Electronic calculators and computers have made it easier to create charts and analyze observations. This might be the best time for amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. Now, you might need to travel 80 km to see a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. During the day, airplane trails can stay in the sky for hours and turn into clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices. There are many things to do and many options. People always want the newest product or service, and technology makes changes happen faster. New products come out quickly, and it can be overwhelming. More choices can mean more stress, less time, and more complexity. People are now looking for 'simplexity' - simple things that bring meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and more software updates and phone plans than we can follow.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it is very important to us. We do not let anything change this tradition. The people who stay at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I do not like the rude behavior of shop assistants today, and I do not like waiters who try to be too friendly. I know the names of most of the other guests because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them in the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. It is hard to find such respect for privacy in hotels these days.

**Othello**
A special performance of Shakespeare's play "Othello" has moved from Stratford to London. This gives me a chance to correct a review I wrote when the show first started last spring. I said Ray Fearon was too young to play Othello and criticized his acting. I still think it's not right to ignore the age difference between Othello and Desdemona, but I was wrong about Mr. Fearon's acting. His performance is amazing. The whole cast is excellent. Some memorable scenes include Cassio's dangerous games with other officers and the moment when Iago starts to lose control. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very emotional. The pace and tension are great throughout the play. Don't miss this production.
**Lake Vostok**
In the middle of Antarctica, there is no movement. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But on the large white plateau inside, there is no life. Except for a huge hidden lake called Lake Vostok, which is under almost 4 kilometers of ice, right below the coldest place on earth. The water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths and find out what strange creatures live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For two years, researchers from around the world have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets. If they succeed, the next few years will be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.
**Scientists**
There was an interesting discussion on the radio last week. It seems that some scientists are very excited about why they become scientists. The phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's the old search for knowledge, the wish to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we want to know all this in the first place and why science can't explain our curiosity. It seems more important to know if what scientists are doing is right, rather than getting stuck in debates about the purpose of it all. I think the key issue is not why we do science, but to understand that science is a tool, and we should decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Food**
Food is very important and makes us feel good. Many people think cooking is only for special occasions or difficult dishes, but that's not true. You can make a tasty soup by just putting some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs in water. This is better than buying soup in a packet or can. Instead of buying a chocolate mousse with lots of chemicals, you can make a delicious one in five minutes that everyone will love. Cooking is a way to show care and love. Sharing food is important in our lives, which is why we celebrate birthdays, anniversaries, and other events with meals. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party! And people usually don't discuss business deals over canned soup.
**In the Elevator**
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms and other documents were piled up, waiting to be organized. He also had many books and journals near the new bookshelves. As he went up in the elevator, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She was always punctual and neat. He wondered how she would react to the mess. Maybe she would think someone had broken in. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, came while he was trying to tidy up. He hoped she would help, but she just went into his apartment, which was her responsibility. She thought of him as someone from far away, not from her world in Brooklyn.
**KAREN**
Karen wanted to be different from her mother, so she created her own story of strength. A key moment was when she was twelve, and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. She thought she would be blind, but the doctor said her eye was fine, and she only needed a few stitches. When she saw her mother in the doctor's office, talking about miracles, Karen felt she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**
Miss Fogerty was walking across the village green, feeling both excited and sad. She had just learned something important, which was exciting because her life was usually quiet. But she was also very sad about Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years and was always kind and patient. He made people feel like he had all the time in the world to listen to their worries. This made him very loved in the village. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor, and in return, he received loyalty and affection.

**Joanna's Lessons**
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. But she also writes books for young children learning the piano. Joanna is known for her amazing piano skills. She plays many types of music, like classical, jazz, and blues. At a concert for kids, one boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna found it funny and played it, showing she is a real pianist in the boy's eyes.
Joanna is different from many top pianists because she cares about how children learn the piano. She wrote a piano book for kids called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World." She did this even though she has a very busy schedule. She is involved in many music festivals, runs her own recording label, and likes to work with other artists.
Joanna believes the first piano lessons are very important. She thinks music should be for everyone, not just for those who want to be stars. When she was younger, she taught beginners and saw many children learn piano at her home, where her mother was a piano teacher. She wants everyone to have a chance to learn music, just like learning to swim or speak a little French.
Some children learn piano quickly, but Joanna is interested in those who take their time. Many kids stop learning because they feel pressure to be perfect. Joanna worries that some parents push their kids too hard in music, like in sports. She thinks music should be fun and enjoyable.
Joanna's piano books are colorful and have stories to make learning fun. She includes different music styles for teachers or parents to play with the child. If parents can't play, the music is on CDs. Joanna believes learning should be fun and encourages kids to try different things on the piano.
As children get better, they need to learn to read music, not just play by ear. Joanna understands this because she also relied on her ear when she was young. But she knows practice is the most important thing. She didn't practice a lot until she went to the Royal Academy of Music. Now, she practices eight hours a day, which is very important to her.
Joanna says the key to practice is knowing what you want to achieve. She suggests playing the whole piece, even with mistakes, and mixing hard and easy pieces.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson once said that writing without effort is often not enjoyable to read. This means that good writing is usually difficult to create. When I look at my old school essays, I notice there are not many mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand is hard work. Writing slowly helps you think carefully. When you write by hand, you are more careful because it is hard to change or erase. But with computers, it is easy to be careless. Many writers find that they spend as much time fixing their computer drafts as they did writing by hand. Also, emails are not as personal as handwritten letters. Some people say emails have brought back the art of love letters, but they often lack the emotion and care of handwritten ones. Words on a screen can seem boring and are often written quickly without much thought.
**The CD**
I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not special, but the shiny disc inside was interesting. "Aren't they amazing?" Mr. Warriston said when he came back. I agreed and gave the disc to him carefully. "It's incredible they can hold seventy minutes of music," he said, turning on the music player. He pressed a button, and a small drawer came out. He put the disc in and pressed the button again, and the drawer went back in. "Some people say they sound too clean, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over like records?" I asked. "No," Mr. Warriston said. "You only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He looked confused and then thoughtful. "I don't know. You could have two sides and double the music..." He looked at the machine. "You could have two lasers or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Good question." He pointed to my chair. "Let's get you in the best spot to hear the music." I was happy to ask a question he couldn't answer.
**Books versus Electronic Text**
Malcolm Bradbury said that if matches were invented after lighters, we would think they were amazing. People often say electronic text is as important as the invention of printing, but they forget that big changes take time. In 1979, a book said that books would disappear in the 1980s. That was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is not enjoyable, so most people don't do it. Computers make it easy to read small parts of text. Some people say this is a new way of storytelling, but reading parts of a book is not new. Many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, are not read from start to finish. The problem with computers is that they don't encourage reading a whole text.
**The Office**
Charles walked into the office and saw everything was in order. The carpet was clean, and the desk was just as he remembered it. Files were in their drawers, and trade journals filled the shelves. Kathleen tried to close the filing cabinet and then spoke to him. "You need to use computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, looking at the room. He didn't think about adding a computer or any machine, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. They had talked about this many times. She didn't understand why he didn't like technology, even though he was good with computers and had written an important paper about them. She was the reason for that paper. She could use a keyboard to change any software into something new.

"You don't take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She wasn't really asking because she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She sometimes forgot because he wasn't supposed to be there often. But now, he was there all the time. He realized that if he stayed away, things would go wrong. He thought about how he went from being an important advisor, meeting authors and playwrights for lunch, to someone always trying to stop problems, with no parking space at work. "This came," she yelled, waving a folder. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." It also said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot didn't want to see another synopsis. He wanted to see a "First Draft." Ian Cuthbert had been given a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, but Lancelot realized it was a mistake to ask friends to write books. Ian was unpredictable. Lancelot read the synopsis and recognized almost everything. He closed the folder. It seemed Ian's manuscript would never come. The synopsis was not brilliant and felt like Ian had lost interest. Lancelot remembered a famous author whose last book was published incomplete after his death. Ian's advance was large, which was not a good business decision. Lancelot remembered when Ian was a promising talent at Cambridge. Ian's friends took over British theatre quickly, but Ian's talent stayed hidden. He was difficult to work with. He was supposed to edit an arts magazine but never published it. He had a contract with a fashion magazine but didn't produce much. At meetings, Ian was critical and didn't like others' ideas. Ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot was starting to think that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the beginning.

'The change in breakfast habits in England
Health experts say breakfast is very important. But in history, breakfast is quite new in England. In medieval times, breakfast was not often mentioned in stories. Sometimes, travelers ate early before long trips, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles. 
In the sixteenth century, breakfast became normal for everyone. Some people think this happened because there was more food available. But there were also big social changes. For example, people started working set hours, often starting very early. So, eating in the morning became necessary, not just for the rich.'

**Photography**
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and experiences. They also think about social and cultural rules. In this book, we will see how these things change the style, content, and feeling of a photo. We will also learn how people look at and react to these images. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they might think they understand the photos. But instead of just accepting the photo as it is, we can ask if it really shows what happened. Does it show the photographer's opinion? Is the exact moment important, or is the photo a symbol of something bigger in the world?
**More than a Game**
For me, sport is more than just playing. The best people in sport believe in themselves completely. You need to focus only on your goal if you want to succeed. There is only one way to be the best, and you have to ignore everything else. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. You either succeed or fail. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, and it also shows the value of working in a team. My sport lets you be great on your own, but it is also a team game, so you have to balance both. It's like life - you can do well alone, but you must remember others are around you. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has opened many opportunities for me and let me see things around the world that others might not see. But you also have to give up a lot for these benefits.
**Tuning In**
Some experiences stay very clear in our memory. For me, one special moment happened one night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a mockingbird singing beautifully from a tree. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's amazing singing kept me awake. As I listened to its complex songs, I felt like I was in a new artistic world. To understand the bird's music, I thought about my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was hearing a special, live performance. I reacted with surprise and joy as the bird sang different tunes through my open window, until I finally fell asleep.

People have always had strong feelings about birds. But what do these feelings say about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. 
In a greenhouse, a small brown bird called a wren is hitting the glass. Some people think wrens bring messages or signs. Is it trying to tell me something, or is it just stuck? Maybe both are true. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people believed the direction a wren flew could bring good or bad luck. Today, we still see wrens in art and decorations in many British homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, wrens are still important to us. A forest without wrens feels empty. 
This connection with birds comes from old stories and beliefs. In the past, people depended on nature to survive and created stories to explain the world around them. These stories can change over time. For example, the red kite bird was once common in London and seen as helpful. Later, people thought of them as pests, and they disappeared from most places except Wales. Now, red kites are protected and are a symbol of conservation in Britain.
Our connection with birds is deep and goes back to early human history. Early humans watched birds to learn about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. When we think about why birds matter to us, we also think about what it means to be human. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and want to understand.
Some people might think our feelings about birds are old and not important now. But like parts of our body we don't need anymore, losing these feelings can be hard. Birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger, which is sad not only because we lose these birds but also because we lose part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have special meanings in stories and poems. Losing them is a cultural loss.
Folklore, or traditional stories, is important. These stories have a strong connection to birds and are more powerful than scientific facts. They help us feel and understand things about birds that science can't explain. Whether we watch birds on TV or in our gardens, the joy we feel is hard to describe with science. Birds are fascinating, and the stories we tell about them help us understand their messages. The wren in the greenhouse is like a puzzle, connecting the present with the past and future, and it keeps me curious.

**Maps**
A map shows how places and features on Earth relate to each other. This is done using distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like "a day's walk" or "a day's journey by river." This told more about how easy it was to travel through the area than the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far is it?" Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time, just like maps. Even today, some maps, like train maps, might not show true directions. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks along a route, and these signs could be realistic or symbolic. The style of these signs changed depending on the map's purpose and where it was made. So, when studying old maps, it's important to understand the style used.
The history of making maps, or cartography, is about getting better at showing distance and direction accurately and adding more details to maps. To improve maps, cartographers used other sciences. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, they used the magnetic compass. They also created tools to measure angles accurately. As people explored more of the world, they tried to map it. Astronomers found out that Earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flat at the poles, which helped improve maps of large areas.
Over time, different people needed maps for different reasons. Travelers and merchants were not the only ones using maps. Soldiers needed accurate maps for planning battles, especially with the use of artillery. This led to the invention of contour lines to show land features. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also needed maps for their work. Today's map makers, or cartographers, create maps showing many things, like rock layers, weather patterns, and land use. The value of maps in many sciences has led to a modern revival of map-making.
The development of maps has not always been smooth. There have been times of slow progress and times of fast development. Sometimes old ideas stayed around even when new ones were available. Cartographers often knew how to improve maps but had to wait for better tools. Since it was easy to copy old maps, and because a lot of money was invested in printing them, map makers were sometimes slow to accept new ideas. Therefore, maps should not always be seen as perfect evidence of what people knew at the time. The many maps we have today show a lot of human effort and thought. They are a valuable record of human history, making the study of old maps both interesting and educational.

'TIM RICE I was invited into a young man's living room, which was a nice and organized space compared to the messy rooms around it. Moving from the kitchen to his living room felt like going from economy to business class on a plane. He had the biggest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across, and he had even bought Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as crazy; I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams were not as serious to me, though I can say that now. They might have been if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy dream for me, to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein, I was willing to try. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very good. As he played more music from shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' record collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for praising his music and a seven-inch single of a song I had written, which an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier. We promised to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but on the bus back to my flat, I thought I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be crazy to miss the chance to work with him. Even if we didn't become top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a lawyer, my brief certainty of a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber faded a bit. I would keep looking for groups needing a vocalist and write more simple songs that suited my voice, but it seemed likely I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would probably have outgrown pop music, as my father predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This was worrying because if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and write lyrics like musical lyricists instead of pop stars. Andrew was interesting and talked about good food and Victorian architecture, and he supported Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was clear, and he said he had all the contacts. I soon returned to his living room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded orphanages. His story was worthy, but it didn't really excite me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version, and the project was not very original, similar to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. However, Andrew's belief in his music's brilliance was contagious and not completely wrong. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent for over twenty-five years, said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there is room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the songs meant to be funny. Andrew explained the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the title, most of which had probably been thought up by his previous lyricist friend. I skipped a day at the lawyer's office, pretending to be sick, to write my first set of theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it that day, but I had changed careers.'

**Language**
Humans have a special ability: we can communicate with each other very precisely using language. Language is so important in our lives that it's hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will probably start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to talk naturally, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders didn't learn web-making from a special spider school; it's something they just know how to do.
**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather, created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can change how landscapes look. For example, warm and wet weather all year helps tropical jungles grow, which have many different species. On the other hand, cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather patterns, which make up the climate over time, happen because large amounts of air move and mix. The air moves because the earth spins, and the air doesn't move as fast as the earth. The sun is also a big reason for air movement.
**Coffee**
As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and make coffee, which was a bit scary. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I spent several days learning how to make coffee, especially how to clean and use the restaurant's espresso machine. I also learned how to make a perfect cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized making good coffee was harder than it looked, and I thought I might be moved to simpler tasks like cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. He said, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn how to do it well."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often fail with programs about visual arts like painting and sculpture? These should be easy for the camera to show because it can display the whole artwork and then zoom in on details. However, there are few TV series that successfully show both the enjoyment and complexity of looking at art. A good example of this problem is Robert Hughes's series "American Visions," which is about American art. Hughes is a trustworthy critic with a strong personality, and he had almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often ignored by British galleries. I thought the series would focus on great artworks, but instead, it was more about how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known for taking risks. The metals market is less controlled than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, you can make a lot of money. Taking risks is a normal part of this industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. But now, the economists who said the market would keep the price of rare metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being taken out of the ground, and the cost of raw materials is going down. Considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a large company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its nearby small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something special. To get around the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If your room doesn't include one, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. Or, you can rent a boat if you want to travel on your own. Sailing is the most popular way to get around here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a good reason. The calm, protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. It's not only at sea that you can find treasures. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Title: Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK
At the Bamboo Bike Club in London, you can join a course to build your own bamboo bike. The club is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. They offer a weekend course where you can create a custom bike frame designed on a computer.
Bamboo is becoming popular in bike building. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire have brought back this old method. However, buying a ready-made bamboo bike can be expensive, costing around $2,995 or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable, so they started their own business.
Instead of just selling bikes, they wanted to share the fun of making them. The Bamboo Bike Club is more like a community project. James and Ian both have full-time jobs; James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. They run monthly courses where you can build your own bike for a reasonable price.
During the course, you learn how to choose strong bamboo and make strong joints. You start by building the front triangle of the bike with bamboo tubes. Metal tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. James and Ian help you with every step, making sure everything is done correctly.
Building the bike yourself is a big part of the fun. Even if you make mistakes, you can try again with a new piece of bamboo. On the second day, you wrap the joints with hemp and glue them with epoxy resin to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts.
Bamboo bikes are strong and can last a long time. Ian has used his bike for over a year on a long commute, and James has tested his off-road. The bikes are designed to be very strong, even more than needed.
Bamboo bikes look different from professional metal bikes. They might look a bit rough, but they are unique. James and Ian believe that this individuality is important. Bamboo bikes are great for a relaxed ride, not for racing. They are light and smooth to ride, making them fun to use.
The best part? You can build your own bamboo bike for less than £500.

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she found a book by Dr. John Gray, a pop psychologist. She thought the book would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book is about how men and women can communicate better. This book is very popular in the self-help industry, which is growing fast. People in America want to improve their lives, and these books try to help them. The self-help industry is also important for New York publishing. In Britain, many self-help books are published, but not all are good. Many books are rejected because they are too similar to others or too specific. Editors look for books that can sell well. They ask questions like, "Is the author easy to promote? Is the idea interesting to many people?" Dione Reverend says that a catchy title is very important for a book's success.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement with the reader that they are telling the truth. However, writers often do not tell the whole truth. They might leave out things that are too embarrassing or seem unimportant. Sometimes, writers make up stories to show a deeper truth about themselves. Some writers might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. Readers might think they are reading a true story, but it could be fiction. This is not always done to deceive people.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Detective stories became popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. These stories often show the conflicts in society. A crime in a detective story represents human desires like greed, and solving the crime shows how society can work well again. In Dashiell Hammett's stories, society is shown as corrupt. The detective and the criminal understand each other. The detective is both a part of the law and a bit of a criminal. He is both a crook and a competitor. Sometimes, the detective feels connected to the criminal, and sometimes he is very eager to catch them because of this connection.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at the Grand Hotel to talk about writing. Gould believes that to write well about science, you need to understand the scientific community. He says you should never write down to the reader. You can make the language simpler, but you should not change the main ideas. If readers feel they are being talked down to, they will not like the writing.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym in the City of London, the air feels very cold. This gym is popular with people who work nearby. Because of the very hot summer, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, it feels as cold as the Arctic inside. This is an example of how people often use too much air-conditioning. Air-conditioning is now a big part of our lives, showing how we can change the climate around us. But many buildings could stay cool in other ways. They could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls that keep out heat during the day and release it at night. These simple ideas can really help and would mean we need less air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are interested in sundials again. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches got better, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are interested in them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. Sundials are calm and romantic, reminding us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I used to think china-painting was only for very skilled people. I once saw older women at an arts show painting teacups with perfect flowers. They were so good that it seemed like they had been doing it for many years or were just very talented. I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners be as good? But when I visited a class, it was not scary at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers quickly like a machine.

Uncle chose a holiday package for Keith and Dawne at a good price. It included a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent told them that they would be with a school group learning Italian. However, something went wrong. Instead of Venice, Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss in Switzerland.
At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their details and said everything was fine. On the plane, they noticed people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.
When they arrived, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. Keith thought there was an overnight stop, but when they reached the hotel, it was late, and they were tired. They accepted the room for the night. The next morning, they realized they were booked for the whole holiday in Switzerland. The receptionist told them about the lake and boat trips to Interlaken.
Keith tried to explain the mistake, saying they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, tried to help. She explained that many holidays have similar tickets and labels, which might have caused the mix-up.
Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left to check, and Keith thought about everything that happened. An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, talked to them about how well they slept.
