Keith and Dawne realized the irony: they wanted a holiday away from elderly people, but ended up on a tour with them. Uncle had suggested the trip to help them escape the demands of older people.

Title: Ernest Shackleton: A Model for Modern Management
American business leaders are now looking at Ernest Shackleton, a famous polar explorer, as a great example of good leadership. In Britain, many people know about Shackleton and his adventures. However, in America, he is only recently becoming popular. The Wall Street Journal called him "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements were mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are very interested in him. Books about his journey on the ship Endurance are being written, and a big exhibition is being prepared by the American Museum of Natural History. Columbia Tristar is also making a movie about his life.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his leadership and communication skills. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, has been inspired by Shackleton for many years. His company deals with communication during difficult times, like when a company's factory has an accident or when many employees are laid off. MacGregor believes Shackleton is a great example because he was a strong leader and communicator. Shackleton made tough decisions, like turning back from the South Pole in 1908 to save his team, showing that he valued their lives above all.
Shackleton's most famous expedition was in 1914 when his ship, the Endurance, got stuck in ice and was eventually crushed. Despite this, Shackleton kept his team safe and motivated. He planned carefully, kept his men informed, and was open to their ideas. He was adaptable and ready to change plans if needed. MacGregor says Shackleton's story helps clients understand leadership without feeling criticized.
Shackleton believed an explorer needed optimism, endurance, and patience. MacGregor points out that sometimes doing nothing is the hardest thing, especially in America, where people want quick solutions. Shackleton showed that sometimes it's better to wait and not rush into decisions. He also led by example, like when he gave his gloves to a team member who didn't have any or shared a biscuit when food was scarce.
Caroline Alexander, who wrote a book about Shackleton's expedition, says people today admire heroic efforts like Shackleton's because they feel there are not many true heroes now. Shackleton stands out as a real example of the ideals people miss today.

'Finding Food in Madagascar's Forests In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. It lives a bit like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye look for insect larvae inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to make holes and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop out the insects. Scientists have known about the aye-aye's feeding habits for over a hundred years, but only recently learned how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of some aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and Annabelle. He wanted to see if they found insects by looking for signs on the wood, like small holes. He gave them logs with drilled holes. Some holes had mealworms, and others were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food, without needing to see the holes. Dr. Erickson tested if they used smell or sound to find the insects. Even when the smell was blocked, the aye-ayes found the mealworms, even if they were dead and silent. So, how did they find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes tap the wood with their middle finger and listen with their big ears. They might be using echo-location, like bats, to find hollow spaces where insects might be. The aye-aye might also hear insects moving when it taps. Some people think the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar, but there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also look for insects in wood. The aye-aye is like a mix of a woodpecker, a bat, and a squirrel. Its teeth grow like a squirrel's, and it can also open nuts with its long finger to eat the inside.'

'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we really know what their lives were like when they were young? Old diaries give us small, incomplete glimpses, and family stories are often forgotten. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do it. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they are still just images. Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary ones. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was disappearing. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "People say they do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it themselves." The promise of privacy helps people be honest. A 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune said, "I was surprised at what came out. There were painful things, like my divorce." He did it for his family, hoping they could learn something, but hasn't let his children read it yet. He thinks they should read it after he is gone. He also saw patterns from his childhood that led to repeated mistakes. Ms. Renier has noticed this in others too. "It's amazing how many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "Things from childhood affect them for life. They marry people their parents would like or do the opposite to rebel." Many people still feel disappointed about things with their parents, even 60 years later. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed, and some want to say, "I can't stand my mother." Ms. Renier listens but doesn't judge. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to be nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then aren't sure if it should be included. I put it in, and they can remove it later. But usually, people want to be honest." "It's not about showing off. Things are changing fast, and we are losing touch with the past. This gives us roots. We need a connection to our ancestors because families don't stay together like they used to. People want a little immortality." Each book takes up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story. Modern technology helps her make everything except the book cover. You can choose your own cover color and title. The books are interesting to the family they are for and are not about revealing secrets. Ms. Renier organizes the material well, and the final book is as good as its subject. The book looks nice and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be more affordable," she says. "But the people I've worked with are usually wealthy, like readers of Harpers & Queen, where I advertise. They are the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted for their descendants."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, nothing here is real. All sculptures are copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with great natural light. The good thing about plaster casts is that sculptures originally shown together but now in different museums across Europe can be seen together again. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery showing different photography exhibitions. We offer courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a Beginner's Course, a short Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members program, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books, magazines, and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from all geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection, made by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, added a lot to the collections, making the museum outstanding. The collection is organized by geological age, showing major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**
There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos across Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be bought and usually take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world. It is a unique tourist attraction where you can create wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred brass plates from tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center makes resin copies, called facsimiles, to preserve the originals while allowing people to enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates were used as memorials instead of statues and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed in revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and the Cambridge Centre has a wide range of examples.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**
I have had 35 years of being around small children because of my unusual personal life. I have loved every moment of it. This morning, I fed the baby, and for me, that is what being a father is all about. I am very lucky with my children. We all love opera, theatre, books, and music. This creates a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I am more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in hitting children. I have slapped my children in anger, but I don't support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I am here if they need me, but I let them call me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't called, you make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**
I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and clothes. This has been very helpful for running my agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy starting my business, so I missed some things like their first concerts and sports days. I feel sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising award ceremonies with us without feeling shy. I think it helps that I do something they find glamorous and interesting.
**C. The Politician**
My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if there are facilities for the kids to come with me. This way, they know what I do when I am not with them, and there is no feeling of Daddy disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all realizing the need to involve our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**
My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about being a father. I tried hard to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even lived next door to each other for a while, so the kids could come and go as they wanted, but I think they found that confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too liberal. I think I could have been more organized. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.
**E. The TV Presenter**
I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house. We thought, "Why keep spending money on new sofas when we could have a kid instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you also become just another parent. It's a great equalizer. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at her smile makes it all better. A baby's smile is the best way to make you feel happy. It can melt a grown man.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**
A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
This is a play by Marlowe about a powerful warrior. It is very long, but in Terry Hands' version, it is exciting and fast. Antony Sher plays the main role and does amazing stunts, like jumping from a balcony. He keeps the audience's full attention with his strong performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall was first shown in Manchester. It starts with two married couples talking in a garden, but then it becomes a deep story about illness. Michael Wall was a talented writer who died young.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish writer, tells a story about the fishing industry in Wexford, Ireland. The play has strong characters and emotions, with some funny moments. It can be a bit slow, but it ends with a powerful scene.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar but has clever twists.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
E. **The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about tricksters from the 17th century. The play was first shown in Stratford and is now at the Barbican. The actors give great performances as the con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James directs this comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society. It was successful in Edinburgh and is now in London. The play is well-acted and stylish.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*
G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a fun version of Beauty and the Beast set in London. It has beautiful music and celebrates romantic love. It's a feel-good show.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*
H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's version of Shakespeare's comedy is not very good, but it has great comic performances by Ron Cook and Anton Lesser. Most of the other actors seem uncomfortable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This play by Granville Barker is about a lawyer who leaves a dishonest financial situation to his son. It is a great story and is now touring different regions.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to turn her against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very exciting. She is trapped in the basement of an old house. This book shows details of family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always the protectors they should be. It's an important and believable story.
**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together to solve a mystery about a 1915 train accident that killed eight people. They find out that their relatives were involved. The story uses different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts to help the reader understand what happened. It's a smart and complex story that needs careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit well into her family or her male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons. When he leaves to find work, Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes, even though she has problems with her stressed mother. The story is set in 1930 and has a strong message that there are different kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
In this story, Rose, a mature woman, leaves her materialistic life and rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage with her two children. A fierce cat and strange things in the house reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The local people become hostile, and Rose's family is in danger. By the end, the threat is controlled, but Rose is upset by her teenage son's actions. It's a gripping story.
**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam is from the poorer side of the family and is impressed by his rich cousin, Lisa. When Lisa's world falls apart, Sam helps her find balance. They both learn about reality and the importance of family. The story is a bit slow in parts but has gentle humor. The growing friendship between the two teenagers is well done. It can interest both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Robbie works as a gardener for Stanley, an elderly man. At first, Robbie finds Stanley interesting, but later he is repelled by him. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium and his plans, the story becomes thrilling. The book is set in New Zealand and is unusual and engaging.
**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has troubled relationships and a difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick improves his self-worth through a role in a school play and with the help of a caring teacher. It's highly recommended, even though it's a painful read, especially at the end.

Title: 'Science and Weightlessness: A Unique Flight Experience'
Journalist Tom Mumford joined students on a special flight to test their science ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, the plane looked normal. It was a Boeing KC-135, built in 1964, similar to a Boeing 707. But inside, it was different. The plane had a long white tunnel with few windows and lights along the walls. Most seats were removed, except a few at the back where 13 students from Europe and America sat, looking nervous.
For a year, these students competed to join this flight, organized by the European Space Agency. They had to come up with creative experiments to do in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a spot on this unusual flight, which felt like a wild roller-coaster ride. For two hours, the plane flew up and down like a giant bird. At the top of each curve, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane went higher on its own before falling back to Earth. During these moments, everything inside the plane became weightless, and the students felt like they were closer to the moon than Earth.
The flight started smoothly, but soon the plane climbed at a 45-degree angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, and we felt the blood leave our heads. Then, the engines stopped, and we were weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, feeling like we were dancing in the air. Moving around was confusing because directions like up or down no longer made sense.
After ten seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned suddenly, and some students landed hard. There were 30 curves in total, giving ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They used a device to turn it over in the air. A German team from the University of Aachen looked at how metal joins are affected by no gravity, thinking about future space stations. Students from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films in microgravity. They believe these sails could use the sun's energy like a yacht uses the wind.
After two hours of flying up and down, we felt a bit sick, but mostly excited. One student said, 'It was unforgettable. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more.'

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology." He talks about a unique time in his life when he didn't experience any summers. He traveled to New Zealand every summer in the UK, which is winter in New Zealand, so he had nine winters in a row. He enjoyed this because he likes winter.
His parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land in New Zealand for him and his siblings to take care of. His mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, they would always have a connection to New Zealand, where their father grew up. They found land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was suitable for planting trees.
Jonathon was excited about the idea because he loved working with land. He had spent a year in Australia working on farms, so planting trees sounded great to him. He started planting in 1968, and by 1972, he and his siblings had planted trees on the entire 70 acres.
In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand, making it a challenging but happy time for Jonathon. Every morning, he faced the cold and wet weather to plant trees. He worked with an experienced tree-planter, which helped him learn. They used a planting bag to carry trees and had to line up poles to plant in straight lines. Jonathon enjoyed the hard work, and it made him fit. Over time, he developed a rhythm for planting, which made the job easier.
While planting, Jonathon had time to think about life and nature. These thoughts influenced his future work. He has returned to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow, which makes him happy. He worries about bad weather affecting the trees but is glad they are now 20 years old and healthy.
In 1984, Jonathon took a break from teaching and spent three months alone in New Zealand. He wrote his first book, "Seeing Green," in a small cabin on the tree farm. He feels a strong connection to the land and believes it is a powerful bond between people and the earth.

**Caring for Badgers**
"What now?" I thought when a helper handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an "open farm" six years ago. We are known for taking care of orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange, like a mix between a laugh and a bark. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft like velvet, and they had milky-colored eyes on their black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between January and March and live underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger and are never found. These three were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. The mother was dead, and the babies were still with her. They were healthy but cold and crying. After removing their fleas, I took them to the kitchen and put them by the stove to warm up. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to mimic their mother licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though unsteadily. They seemed happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute "mom."
Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was not as active, even though he was eating normally. This was a warning sign. I didn't act quickly enough, and the next morning, I found him dead. The vet said Willow died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, as liquid can go into the lungs. This caused an infection in Willow that was hard to treat, even with antibiotics. I was sad about losing Willow but continued caring for the others. Six days later, a local farmer brought me another male cub, abandoned by its mother. The area was too disturbed for her to return, and the cub was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II. He was about two weeks younger than the females and very hard to feed. I had to move the bottle's teat around in his mouth to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and other foods. Willow II was different. He liked the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready for other foods.
At nearly five months old, they were eating cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and plant shoots or roots. My badgers were lucky because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms. By August, the cubs became more active at night and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they played and chased each other. As "human badgers," we joined in their games. I learned to avoid their playful bites, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got bitten and bruised. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely expanding their territory to find food, as badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive to outsiders. We were warned they might enter our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we made the gate more secure with sheet metal.
The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people were interested. We started a project to build a home for the badgers on the farm. With help and advice, we designed a new home for them. Our son Daniel made the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for people to see inside. As the sett was built, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they stopped going for walks and enjoyed their new home. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company called Badgerline helped sponsor it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Later, I checked on them and saw three badgers sleeping soundly in their chambers.
These days, I don't walk with them as often, especially since they wake up at midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she has joined a neighboring sett. Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before running off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

'In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to map compass changes. Anjana Ahuja reports. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was mapping 'compass variations' during his sea trips on the ship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't correct their compasses, making it hard to find their exact position at sea. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time, sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the Atlantic Ocean. The first trip was stopped because of problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these trips, Halley published a map in 1701 showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This map was very useful to sailors for over a hundred years until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate. Dr. Clark, who also loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the same route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the trip, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first expedition across Antarctica, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. 'Halley led an amazing life,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer but also did research in geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and also helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.' Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking the same measurements Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the current model of Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field. 'We usually measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. To measure direction, you need to know true north,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our trip, we can use global positioning satellites to find that.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the Atlantic Ocean. Halley's journey was the first scientific sea expedition, and he was the first civilian made a naval captain for this purpose. Dr. Clark has the experience needed for this journey. He spent two years in Antarctica and works in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. The expedition will have four stages with different crews. Does Dr. Clark share Halley's passion? 'I am ready to spend eight months on this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't cross the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

**POWER DRESSING EVERY SUMMER**
Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This display raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: in a world where animals compete to survive, why do peacocks have such extravagant tails? How do they manage with them?
Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying these peacocks to find answers. Darwin believed that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the strongest and smartest survive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a problem because it is large and not practical. Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection,' where females choose mates based on beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He thought that if peahens chose males with fancy tails, there must be a good reason. Maybe these males had other qualities that helped them survive, even if humans couldn't see them.
Today, the debate continues. At Whipsnade, 200 peacocks live like wild birds but are used to people, making them perfect for study. Petrie and her team are asking two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the showiest tails? And do these males have other advantages, as Wallace thought?
Observations show that peahens do like males with more eye-spots on their tails, which are longer. These males attract more mates. But it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways.
William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and free of parasites, which their bright feathers show. This idea is true for some birds, but Petrie's team hasn't tested it on Whipsnade peacocks yet.
This year, Petrie is comparing the children of attractive and unattractive males. Do the children of attractive males grow faster or are they healthier? If yes, then the females' choice is practical, as Wallace thought.
There's another idea from R.A. Fisher, a mathematician and biologist. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will have better tails, and their daughters will prefer long tails. This cycle could make tails longer over time. This idea supports Darwin's thought that females might choose beauty just for beauty's sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with new technology. Most of these boats are based on designs from 25 years ago. My boat, however, is different. It sits quietly on a creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. Some might think I am a romantic dreamer, but I don't think so. My boat uses old boat design ideas, but modern technology made it easier to build.
Modern technology is important in boat design and building, but it can sometimes make sailing too easy. Many people go to sea to experience the challenges of sailing. I don't think sailors should suffer, but I believe boats should have some basic comforts, like a coal stove for warmth and dry sleeping areas. However, if everything on the boat is automatic, like the sails, it takes away from the experience. A little struggle with the sails is part of being a sailor.
Some boats now have steering positions in the middle, which makes the cabin bigger, like a hotel room. But I think a boat should feel like a boat, not a house. When I bought my old boat, Hirta, the previous owner said it had comfort but no luxury. Hirta had heavy sails, no electric water pump, no fridge, no central heating, and no electronics, but it was the best boat I ever sailed.
Old boats need a lot of care. After I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a new boat I liked, so I decided to build one. The Westerman has been perfect for me. The designer, Nigel Irens, first drew the boat on a napkin, then used a computer to finish the design. We made a model of the boat, like in the old days, and then improved the design on the computer. The final boat was perfect.
The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. It looks timeless, sails smoothly, and feels peaceful inside. This is because it was designed as a sailing boat first, without thinking about furniture. This traditional method works well. The boat is made of wood treated with a special glue, so it doesn't let water in. It has the benefits of a modern boat but looks and feels like a classic one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**
I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors are very good, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff are friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds or take a walk in the garden. I left feeling great and full of energy. This is a perfect place for a stressed working woman. I want to visit again! - Marcella D'Argy Smith
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**
Shrubland Hall is a calm and relaxing place. It has a beautiful library and a conservatory. When you arrive, you get a medical check-up. They call everyone "patients," which was strange for me because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem during my check-up and helped me with it in fitness classes. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry and got a headache on the second day. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit with yogurt. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. The extra treatments are not too expensive. - Liz Gregory
**C. CAREYS MANOR**
Careys Manor is not a health farm. It is a nice old manor with log fires and a big lounge. The food is delicious but not for those counting calories. The hotel has a gym and pool to help burn off the extra calories. There is also a spa bath, steam room, and sauna. They have a sports injury clinic where I got advice for my shoulder injury. Careys is comfortable and luxurious. You can also explore the countryside around it. - Beverly D'Silva
**D. CLIVEDEN**
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens around the estate. Waldo's restaurant has amazing food. I enjoyed a wonderful meal there, especially the sticky-toffee pudding. The next morning, I spent time in the gym and had a facial and aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options if you want them. - Kay Letch
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is delicious but high in calories. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I chose relaxing oils and had a very good sleep after the massage. The place is modern and well-run, with many therapists and beauty rooms. They offer treatments like manicures, pedicures, and facials. Guests include football teams, families, and friends. I would love to visit here once a month. - Eve Cameron

**Natural Talents**
In the last seven million years, humans have become different from chimpanzees, but not by much. We are still more than 98% the same as chimps in our genes. This means that what makes us different from animals is a recent change. Our ability to make art and do other human things comes from a small part of our genes. Because of this, scientists have found that many things we thought were only human are also done by animals, just in different ways. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'.
The first human art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we can't find these because they don't last over time. The first clear human art we know of is from the Cro-Magnons, about 35,000 years ago, with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
People say human art is different because it is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned, not instinctive. Let's look at these ideas:
1. **Not Useful**: Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means art doesn't help us survive or have children, unlike most animal behaviors. For example, birds sing to defend their area or find a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. Human art seems different because it doesn't do this.
2. **Made for Beauty**: Human art is often made for enjoyment. We can't ask birds if they like their songs, but they mostly sing during mating season, so they probably don't sing just for fun. This makes human art seem unique.
3. **Learned, Not Instinctive**: Human art styles are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds, however, are born knowing their species' song. It's like a French baby raised in Japan suddenly singing the French national anthem without learning it.
Human art changes quickly. Geese honked 2,000 years ago and still do today, but human art changes so fast that even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often tell who painted a work and when. However, two chimpanzees, Congo and Betsy, painted works that looked like human abstract art. Congo even made 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in a London art exhibit in 1957, and many were sold, which some human artists can't say.
These chimp paintings blur the line between human art and animal activities. Like human art, they were not made for practical reasons but for the painter's satisfaction. Some might say human art is different because it is meant to communicate, but even some famous human art was made just for the artist's own pleasure.

Title: A Big Adventure
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored much. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story. 
There are not many big adventures or heroes left today. In the past, children's stories often had brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance. Nowadays, you don't see such people in stories or real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore led a team across the Taklamakan Desert, one of the last unexplored places on earth. The desert's name means 'once entered you never come out', and locals call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home. His team included four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. However, the camel handlers were actually truck drivers, which was a mistake that could have been very dangerous.
This group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a book about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He started the expedition for fun and to find out more about himself. 'I always thought I'd stay in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but I wanted to see who I was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was worried because nobody had done that route before. We went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross, and the desert was kind to us.'
The team faced many hardships: illness, extreme temperatures, thirst, and losing some of their water. 'But', Blackmore says, 'when we were at our limits and the camels had no water for seven days, we found some. We didn't face the desert's famous sandstorms or the cold that could have stopped us. But we had many challenges. The sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the camels, which sometimes fell on us.'
'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. No planes flew over us. Once in the sandhills, we were on our own. I knew I had the mental strength, but I was scared about my physical ability. On the first day, sitting at the desert's edge, it was so hot I couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" I was very scared.'
Towards the end, he said, 'After walking 1,000 kilometers, you don't give up. We were very thin but strong. My body was fit, and my legs were like machines. I could walk over anything.'
In the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking at the moon, and thinking of his family. He says, 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace. When I doubt myself, I remember the desert and think, we did it. I'm prouder of that expedition than anything else. But in life, my family and our happiness are more important.'
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I miss the challenge and open spaces. We had a strong sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Life was becoming too busy for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and save time. However, Susan realized that technology might not be as great as it seems. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which was expensive to fix. This made her question if gadgets are worth the cost and trouble.
Susan started to let her household gadgets go as they stopped working. She wondered what "extra time" technology really gives us. Is it just time to buy more gadgets? She thinks we are being tricked by marketing experts. When her sewing machine started making strange noises, she left it in the backyard. Now, she enjoys sewing by hand, which is quieter and more relaxing. She can take her sewing anywhere in a bag.
There are some gadgets Susan still values, like the washing machine. But getting rid of others, like the color TV, brought unexpected happiness. Without the TV, her family spends more time walking the dog, reading, talking, or doing hobbies. Susan enjoys sewing by hand, even though she used to think it was hard work. She finds it soothing and satisfying to see her work improve.
Sewing by hand allows Susan to listen to the radio or talk with family and friends. She can also watch TV while sewing, feeling less guilty about sitting in front of the screen. Sitting by the fire with a pot of tea while sewing is a cozy experience. Susan used to think sewing by hand was difficult, but now she finds it calming and rewarding. It helps her slow down and enjoy life at her own pace.
Susan also enjoys washing dishes by hand, which gives her time to daydream. She now looks around her house and wonders if she really needs things like the freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. She even thinks about saving money by not using electric lights.

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt visits him at his workshop in East London. When she arrives, Hurst greets her quickly and seems busy. His workshop is full of half-made furniture and different types of wood. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and is well-known for his work. He always has many orders, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want good furniture, Hurst is the person to go to.
Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding someone like Hurst, who makes simple and well-crafted pieces, is rare. Hurst is not happy with some modern furniture because it is often poorly made. He does not like mass-produced furniture and believes in making high-quality pieces. This focus on quality is part of his success, along with his talent. Hurst is confident in his skills and says he has a natural ability for making things.
Hurst learned his craft by asking questions and teaching himself. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return to him for more furniture. He finds it satisfying to furnish a whole house. However, he admits that working with clients can sometimes be difficult, especially if they are unsure of what they want. He prefers clients who know exactly what they want.
Hurst appreciates other talented craftsmen and admits there are people better than him. He criticizes those who take too long to make one piece of furniture and those who try to make fashion statements with their work. For Hurst, furniture should be practical and useful. Despite his confidence, Hurst is humble and says, "After all, I am only making furniture," as Joanna leaves.

'Three ideas about why we sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. But, scientists still do not fully agree on why we need to sleep so much. There are three main ideas. The first and most popular idea is that sleep is important for our body. It says that we sleep to keep our body healthy. While we sleep, our body fixes any damage from the day and makes us ready for the next day. The second idea is about learning. It says that sleep helps us understand and remember what we learn during the day. Without sleep, we would not learn well. The third idea is about energy. It says that we need sleep to recharge, like charging a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

**Eccentrics**
An eccentric is someone who behaves differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. It could be a love for entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing angry letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity is about being unique. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be different and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains pushing against each other on the same track. One train is called individualism, and the other is conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel like we belong. This is stronger than wanting to stand out and be different.
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find others like them. They form clubs, have meetings, and organize events to share their interests. They look for people who understand them, as their family and friends might think they are odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, feels comforting.
We all feel a pull between being unique and fitting in. We might follow the crowd but still want to show we are different. For example, someone might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me." We can choose to be more individualistic and show our personality. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, an American singer, said, "When you feel in your gut what you are doing and then pursue it, don't back down and don't give up."
However, being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric. If a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a hostess makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these actions until they become a natural part of who they are, then they might be considered eccentric. True eccentricity is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care about what others think. They do what they do because of who they are.
This makes eccentrics different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of the world and react to it. Some want to impress society, and some want to escape it, but they are aware of it. Eccentrics, however, continue on their own path without worrying about society.

**Natural Books**
We asked four nature experts to share the wildlife book that influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've met many important people in this field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small but strong woman. She was central to environmental issues in post-war Europe. Her book, *The Home of Man*, is about the rapid growth of cities and the need for sustainable development. It is the most important book I've read on this topic.
**B. Linda Bennett**
When I read *Signals for Survival* by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a herring gull colony. This book explains how animals communicate. After reading it, watching a gull colony becomes fascinating. You can see how they interact and recognize family groups. Niko Tinbergen, a famous behaviorist, worked with wildlife artist Eric Ennion to create this book. Ennion's paintings show the behavior of gulls with just a few lines and colors. This book is perfect for anyone who loves wildlife.
**C. Lee Durrell**
*My Family and Other Animals* by Gerald Durrell is the book that changed my life. It led me to my husband and a career in conservation. I first read it while researching animal sounds in Madagascar. The book lifted my spirits during tough times. It shows a world where animals and people are joyfully connected. Many criticize humans for harming nature, but Gerald Durrell saw all living things as a family. This idea is important for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**
I found *The Shell Bird Book* by James Fisher in my school library in 1966. I was drawn to the beautiful bird paintings by Eric Ennion. I already loved birdwatching and had other bird books, but this one was special. It included information on bird migration, history, and birds in art and music. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. It showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was just as important as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than science, this book opened new possibilities for me.

Title: Do Reviews Help Sell Books?
We asked five top British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:
Publisher A: Reviews are very important for publishers. Many people buy books because of reviews more than ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are less upset by bad reviews. They think any review can help sell books because people want to decide for themselves. Publishers like reviews that match their own thoughts about a book.
Publisher B: Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are often ignored. Reviews help make books and authors known. A good review by a trusted person can increase sales.
Publisher C: Reviews are very important for literary publishers. They help sell books, especially for authors who are not famous. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest opinions. Reviews can help launch a book and a career, but they need help from other things like word of mouth and good marketing.
Publisher D: In the US, a review in the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, reviews don't always have a big impact. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a writer. Some poorly reviewed books sell very well. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer's knowledge than the book itself.
Publisher E: Publishers and writers want long, positive reviews, but they don't always sell books. I once published a biography with great reviews, but it didn't sell well because people felt they didn't need to buy it after reading the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's the review's style or surprise choice of reviewer that can attract buyers.

Making weathervanes is a very old skill, starting from early Egyptian times. Today, Graham Smith keeps this craft alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates special designs for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique and personal item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's work or hobbies.' This is different from the usual cockerel design, which is the most common weathervane. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick, which he made as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. 'I realized there are endless ideas for weathervanes,' he says. Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. 'My old job wasn't artistic, but this is exciting and creative,' he says. 'I love the design part.' Graham has now made over 100 original designs. He works with great detail and always gets the customer's approval before cutting the design by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs because they are popular too. 'People like hand-made things,' Graham says. 'They like to have something a bit different.' Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique items, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike,' he says. 'For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction,' he explains. 'Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine.' Graham is now very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients all over the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are especially interested. 'The price,' he explains, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

Title: Beginner Takes All
Before it was even published, "The Horse Whisperer" was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about what inspired him and his success.
At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans. He is a screenwriter, producer, and wants to be a director. His year started badly when a film project called "Life and Limb," which he had worked on for months, suddenly failed. He was worried because he hadn't earned any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to pay the bank. A sensible person might have looked for a job, like going back to being a TV executive. But instead, Evans made a bold decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.
The idea for the story came from a farrier he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. Its owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. These men were called "horse whisperers." Evans was fascinated and started researching to write a screenplay. But after "Life and Limb" failed, he decided to write a book instead.
In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about his future. By August, he had written half of the book and was back home. The bank was pressuring him, so he showed the book to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was "fine" and said Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts and support his family, but he decided to keep writing.
In October, he sent the first 200 pages and a 12-page summary to seven UK publishers before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. The book was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. They were amazed by the offers, and even Hollywood studios wanted the rights to make a movie.
Evans decided not to write the screenplay for "The Horse Whisperer" because he didn't want to spoil the fairy tale-like success. He wanted to stay involved but not be controlled by the film studios. The success of his book also brought new interest in "Life and Limb," but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. He thought it would be wise to write another novel.

'Young Masters Bobby Fischer is trying to prove himself again in the world of chess. Chess is now more popular with young players. After 20 years away from the game, Bobby Fischer is back and playing against Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game with a great performance, but he is not the same as he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, not in practice, and not in shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess more popular, and now it is more professional. Winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intelligence. The game is very intense: players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose. Now, games last longer, and many are played without breaks. This makes it easier for younger players to succeed. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the world's top ten players, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Players must prepare well before matches, especially because computers have changed chess a lot. A small computer can store one million chess games and help players study their opponents. In one match, both players had teams working to find weaknesses in each other's games. The opening moves of a game are now studied very carefully. Being well-prepared in the opening can decide the game. Today, there are more top players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prize money around the world. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. Losing concentration can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the pressure. The end of the game can be a fast 'time scramble', where players have only seconds to make moves. This is not a time for deep thinking. It becomes a battle of nerves and determination. At the top level, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to rest. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to play again the next day. Most tournaments last 9-11 days, with games every day. World championship matches are even tougher. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to stop because both players were too tired. Karpov lost about 10kg in weight. Can Fischer succeed against these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his leaving the chess world in 1972 surprising. But it also made him a legend. If he returned for money, he will earn a lot. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will become much richer. But if Fischer returned to prove he is still the best, losing could be very disappointing.'

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A. Nick Grosso**
Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's a low-budget film, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know it's difficult. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very exciting."
**B. Simon Pegg**
Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comedy team Funny Business, but working with Steve Coogan has been the most rewarding. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me copying him," Simon admits.
**C. Ciaran McMenamin**
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show was well-received, and his career took off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always going to be successful. Encouraged by his mother, he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for more praise, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for good work."
**D. Neil Taylor**
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company talks about a big hit, but I don't know. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times when I was very depressed, and I've been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."
**E. Stephen Richards**
Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many prizes and awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been touring and giving readings for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express in a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became unhappy with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry being praised, moving to novels is brave. "There's a structure in my poetry, so there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for mistakes. My main goal is not to just produce work without caring about quality."

A. Isabel, the main character in this funny novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but doesn't wear them often because she doesn't want to be seen with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romance books and is looking for the perfect partner. She worries that her knees might stop her from finding love. But she always stays hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with a lot of energy, like an old silent movie, with exciting chapter titles like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired.'
B. This story is about the start and almost end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the view of a smart child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT Radio, a station started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon features a mix of singers, preachers, and soap-opera stars. The small-town setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. The story takes readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old stores, cars, and radios.
C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. Professor Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poet, and he talks about it with his wife's ex-husband. The poet writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help for her brother, who is in prison. The author makes these problems interesting and funny, and the story is enjoyable and clever.
D. Two pairs of best friends, two women and two men, meet in London in the 1960s and stay connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of them, an American businessman named James Hudson, is starting a newspaper, and his friend Richard Blake is the editor. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved, and one of them married, was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is very good. This book is long and detailed, allowing readers to really get to know the characters.
E. This story, written by a great American author, is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty for something he did and decides to take care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, Ian is becoming an unusual bachelor, surrounded by the mess of family life. The story explores many emotions and focuses on the sweet relationship Ian builds with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and lovely book with a perfect mix of sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism: A Discussion**
**A.** Volunteer tourism is when people travel to help build homes or schools in other countries. However, they often pay a lot of money to do this. If this money was given directly to the local community, it might help more than the work the volunteer can do. This is especially true for young people on gap years, who may not have the skills needed. Some studies question if these volunteers are really trying to help or if they just want to improve their own careers. But, these projects can help volunteers learn to act ethically and support those who are less fortunate.
**B.** Volunteering can help people understand each other better, solve conflicts, and participate in global issues. It can also create international friendships. This can be good for both volunteers and the communities they help. However, if only rich people from wealthy countries volunteer, it might only help them and not the communities. These volunteers might use the experience to advance their own careers, rather than truly helping the local people.
**C.** Sometimes, international volunteering can seem like charity from rich countries or a way for volunteers to improve themselves. But it can also be a way to share skills and knowledge between cultures. Volunteering can make people aware of global issues like poverty and injustice, and encourage them to work against these problems for life.
**D.** Volunteer tourism is popular because it seems like a simple way to help others. It avoids big government and business, focusing on personal acts of charity. However, it can also ignore the bigger political issues and reduce development to small acts of kindness. While volunteering is a good thing, it should not replace real efforts to understand and solve global inequalities and poverty.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**
Many people listen to the radio when they wake up and need something to help them get out of bed. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five different models.
One model has a 'dual alarm function.' I thought it meant you could snooze and then wake up again, but it actually lets you set two different wake-up times, like one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model also has a cassette player, which is nice because you can listen to your own tapes. The radio quality is great, but it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn't work. This model was the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, even though the clock sometimes got stuck at 16:00. The digital display is nice, and the snooze bar is easy to use. It has a backup power feature, so you don't have to reset it if the power goes out. However, it was hard to set up, but once we learned how, we felt 'cool' and sophisticated.
Another model has a built-in lamp, but Tom Granger thought it was poorly made. You have to pull the light out of its socket to use it, which made him question its quality. The clock was hard to set, and the light only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but found the radio hard to tune. The buzzer is loud and annoying, like an alarm on a submarine. Despite this, it's the third most popular model on the market.
A model aimed at young people has a bright design and a bootlace strap. Tom Granger and I liked it because it stands out. It was the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm can be off by 10 minutes, which Paul Bridges found unacceptable.
The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said it was easier to set up than modern push-button tuning. The radio quality was fine, and the buzzer worked well, waking me up in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not originally from America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they feel threatened. This makes their spines stick out to protect them. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines because they need to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and only roll into a ball if they have no other choice.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They usually sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, which means they sleep through the winter, but not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

**Great Sports Women on a Winning Streak**
Being successful in sports is difficult for everyone, but women often have to work even harder. Training and competitions take up a lot of time, so they have to make sacrifices. Despite these challenges, many women are overcoming obstacles and setting new records. Here, we talk to some talented British sportswomen who are achieving their dreams.
**A. Jill, 27, Skier**
"I love the feeling of flying through the air and landing perfectly, but it can be scary. Sometimes the weather is bad, but you just have to keep going. We train for ten months a year, so it's hard to have a job outside skiing. You miss out on social life and friends, but I chose this path. In the British team, there are six men and three women. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equally. It's a young sport."
**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and won because I was the fastest, even though I had never cycled before! I earn well as a professional, and there are opportunities for sponsorships. But I worry people think I succeed because of my looks, not my skills. So, I focus on cycling now. I train at least four hours every day, plus stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the time commitment."
**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**
"Rowing is hard for girls to start because few girls' schools offer it. Most start at 19 or 20, making it tough to succeed internationally. Coaches often stay for only a year, so there's little consistency, and the women's team is disorganized. But it's fun, I love being fit, and there's a good social life."
**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**
"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not knowing how big it was! Britain felt too small and safe. I was stubborn and didn't like others controlling me. Now, I'm more tactful. Each walk is different. Walking across Australia was the hardest due to pain. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters, but I got the record! I had to, as my sponsorship money was running out. Men often think women will fail, so sponsoring them is seen as risky."
**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**
"Some men have big egos when driving. If I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its challenges. At corners, men think 'I must beat her,' so I've had many bumps! You need to be competitive and aggressive. It's hard to earn money, and what I make goes back into racing. Women have raced since the 1920s and were seen as unusual. Now, more women are racing each year. I love aiming for the perfect lap in saloon car racing."
**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There's a lot of nervous energy before races, and you push yourself hard. I've asked myself why I do it. The reasons are: a) I'm happier when fit, b) I'm lazy at heart and need to push myself, c) racing is social. Men and women usually compete together, but media coverage focuses mostly on men. Prize money isn't as good for women, but we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission to improve this."

Title: The Day I Met Picasso
Richard Cork remembers meeting the famous artist Picasso when he was 18 years old. Even from far away, Picasso was easy to recognize while he was eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes. Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van before starting university. He had run out of money and found a job painting boats. He loved drawing and had a sketchbook with him when he met Picasso.
Picasso was usually a private person who worked alone in the hills, so Richard was surprised to see him at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Nervously, Richard introduced himself and offered his sketchbook. Picasso kindly signed his name and added a playful drawing on the page.
Richard was very happy and started a conversation with Picasso. Since Picasso's English was not good and Richard's French was also poor, an American woman at the table helped them talk. She called Picasso "the Maestro" and was very excited. Richard told Picasso about his love for art and his admiration for Picasso's work.
