After showing his friend the autograph, his friend suggested that Richard should try to draw Picasso's portrait. Richard went back to Picasso's table and started drawing without asking for permission. Picasso noticed and made funny faces to make it difficult for Richard. He acted like a clown, but Richard kept drawing. Eventually, Picasso stopped moving and let Richard study him quietly. Richard noticed how strong and young Picasso looked, even though he was almost 84 years old.
When Richard finished, the American woman said Picasso wanted to see the portrait. Richard was embarrassed but showed it to him. Picasso liked it and decided to draw Richard in return. In a few quick strokes, Picasso drew a playful version of Richard's face. Richard was amazed and asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso said he had already given his signature.
Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. It was a special moment that meant a lot to him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use many tricks to make you spend more money. Here are some of them:
**A. Freshness Image**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance to make the store look fresh. They might also have a bakery inside, so the smell of fresh bread fills the air. The store might use green colors because people think of fresh food when they see green. Most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh, but the fresh image helps sell everything.
**B. Smart Display**  
Where products are placed in a store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out which parts of the store people visit most. They put the most expensive or fast-selling products there. Shelves at eye level are popular because people notice them first. Special offers in big bins attract people who love bargains. Stores also place related items together, like salad dressings near salads.
**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets put basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, you have to walk past other tempting products. Stores with a good reputation for certain products put them far from the entrance too, hoping you will see other things you want to buy.
**D. Less is More**  
Some stores, like Next, show fewer items on their shelves to make them look special. This makes people think the clothes are exclusive, even though they are mass-produced like other brands. The store's design helps sell the clothes.
**E. Total Temptation**  
People care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items, so not everything is a bargain. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as 'loss leaders.' They also buy in large quantities to get discounts from manufacturers.
**F. Price Tricks**  
In chain stores, people buy fewer items and notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 makes a difference. It also helps reduce theft because staff have to ring up the sale to give change.
**G. Lighting Effects**  
Stores use lighting carefully. Chain stores try to use natural light so clothes look the same as they would outside. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh food look better.
**H. Walking Paths**  
Some stores use different carpets to guide you through the store. These paths are called the 'Yellow Brick Road.' Not all shoppers follow them, so stores like Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths and carpet for sales areas to encourage people to explore.
**I. In-Store Promotions**  
When you enter a supermarket, you might see big pictures of delicious food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use 'video trolleys' with screens that show ads as you shop. These ads are triggered by sensors and aim to make you buy on impulse. The makers say these trolleys increase sales by about 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record by sailing from New York to the Lizard in 10 days. Chris and Robin teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about it in their book "Sea, Ice and Rock."
In 1979, while working on "Quest for Adventure," Chris called Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail, where Chris could teach him climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed, anchored, and then went to shore to climb. Chris was impressed by Robin's calmness in difficult climbing conditions. Robin had never climbed before, so Chris showed him how. Robin then used his own method to climb down safely.
During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a bigger version of their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin's leadership. Robin, as the skipper, usually made decisions but always asked for everyone's opinion first. Chris found sailing boring and preferred being on land, while Robin enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless because Robin didn't really need his help.
The yacht was small, with six people on board, making it crowded. In Greenland, when it was Chris's turn to lead, he found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety while climbing. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was tough. Robin wasn't a natural climber, but he did well. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours but had to turn back. Robin trusted Chris completely and was willing to try again.
The only time they almost had a problem was on the way home. Chris was supposed to take a turn watching the boat at 4 am, but Robin didn't wake him up, thinking he could handle it alone. Chris felt Robin didn't trust him, but Robin reassured him it was a misunderstanding. By the end of the Greenland trip, Chris realized that Robin, despite his tough exterior, was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been with us for a very long time, in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. But in the late 20th century, we risk losing this variety. 
**Prehistoric Apples (8,000 BC)**
People have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In ancient Britain, they spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, people in Switzerland and Italy left apple remains near their homes. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored dried apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and not like the apples we know today.
**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and this knowledge was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apples, but most didn't grow well in Britain. The Normans brought better varieties, and British monks developed new apples. Many Western apples come from these varieties.
**Medieval Favorites (1200)**
In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, known since 1204, was a main dessert apple until the 18th century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296. But due to droughts, the Black Death, and wars, fewer apples were grown, and more were imported. In the 16th century, Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple growing. Harris brought back many apple types, including the famous Pippins, and started a modern orchard in Kent.
**Settler Treasure (1750)**
By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was known for his love of apple trees and his kindness.
**Modern Delicious (1850)**
Around this time in Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge called it 'Delicious', and in 1895, it became one of the most popular apples in the world.
**Granny Smith (1850)**
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was known as 'Granny Smith' and found a new apple tree in 1868. This tree produced the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. She said, "It's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her own background.
**Uniformity (1950)**
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their looks or ability to travel, not taste. This lack of variety is a problem. While some gardeners in the UK keep old apple types alive, the US has lost many apples from 100 years ago. Consumers now want more variety. We need to protect the diversity of apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel. We offer trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. Our trips go to new and unusual places with interesting plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures like tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
Our groups are small, usually 16 people. They are informal and led by experts. This gives you a chance to learn more about the places we visit. You can get closer to the local culture and people. It's an exciting experience for all travelers.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport, often on the same trip. We travel by coach, local bus, train, expedition vehicle, minibus, boat, canoe, raft, camel, light plane, and sometimes on foot. Each trip matches the local area.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who like new experiences. They come mainly from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are aged 25-55. About half are couples, and the rest are individuals traveling alone.
**Activities and Interests**
Each trip is unique, so we have 8 categories to describe them. Each category highlights a special part of the tour. Many factors make our trips successful, like unique places, unusual encounters, and personal involvement.
**Cultural/Adventure**
Most trips have a strong cultural focus. Some tours focus on local cultures and historical sites. For example, trips to Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, India, and China are great for cultural interest. Short walks of 2-4 hours to special sites are often included.
**Wildlife and Natural History**
Our wildlife safaris visit famous game parks and offer exciting animal encounters. In Africa, you can step out of your safari vehicle and explore. You might track gorillas in Zaire or canoe on the Zambezi River. Most safaris camp, but some offer hotel stays. In Asia and South America, we stay in hotels or lodges for game viewing.
**Ethnic Encounters**
Meeting ethnic or tribal peoples is a special part of our trips. You might meet the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to minimize cultural and environmental impact.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Many trips include easy walks through the countryside. You might stay in hotels or village huts. Your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a daypack.
**Major Treks**
We offer a few major treks for strong walkers. These involve walking at high altitudes in mountain ranges like the Himalayas and Andes. We use support vehicles or pack animals, so you don't carry heavy gear.
**Wilderness Experience**
Exploring remote wilderness areas is thrilling. We visit places like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara Desert. These adventures offer a chance to see exotic new horizons.
**Sailtreks/Seatreks**
These are relaxing holidays. We use local boats like feluccas in Egypt and gulets in Turkey. Our schooner explores Indonesian islands, and a motor yacht visits the Galapagos.
**Raft and River Journeys**
River trips can last from a few hours to several days. They range from small inflatables to exciting whitewater rafting. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon offer unique insights into the local environment.

Richard Nerurkar, a top British long-distance runner, visited a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. This camp is located in Nanyuki, near Mount Kenya, which is covered in glaciers. For three years, Richard trained in Kenya's Central Highlands during winter, but he never trained with Kenyan runners on their home ground until his fourth visit. During this trip, he competed in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in a World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. 
Training at high altitudes helps runners because it increases red blood cells, improving how the body uses oxygen. This is one reason why Kenyan runners are so successful. Richard's first race in Africa was an international cross-country race in Nairobi. Although 41 runners finished ahead of him, most were Kenyan, and he felt he had run well.
Kenyan runners are known for their simple approach to running. They have an easy running style, a simple diet, and a relaxed way of talking. They also love to compete. Richard wanted to understand how they train, so he stayed at the national team training camp at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. The camp is basic, with athletes living in simple dormitories. 
The athletes' day includes three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training in the mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. They run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers. Life at the camp is simple, with basic meals like tea, bread, boiled eggs, ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they bathe in streams from Mount Kenya's glaciers.
Richard left the camp with a greater appreciation for Kenyan runners. He realized their success is not just due to genetics, upbringing, or altitude. The simple lifestyle, hard training, and passion for success are key reasons for Kenya's success in distance running.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**
Advertising is having a tough time. It's not just because of the recession. Advertising started to drop in 1989, even before the recession got serious. The problems with advertising are deeper and happening all over the world. Advertising hasn't kept up with how the economy is changing. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but as more brands and media appear, target markets have become smaller. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.
Think about your shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Many of these won't be advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 items in the store. Over a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. For things like cars, you might buy one every three years, and it might be from your employer. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even with things like candy, medicine, and services, you probably don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.
Compare that to the 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising. The average person buys 400 of those 9,500, and not all because of advertising. That's about 4 percent. So, 96 percent of advertising might be wasted, but nobody knows which part. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about 1 in 16 ads, or 6 percent. The other 94 percent seem wasted.
You might think you're not affected by advertising, but almost everyone thinks that. The truth is, nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is part of using media for advertising. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so waste can't be avoided. But advertising can still be cost-effective. It reaches many people to find the few who will respond. Media advertising works because it's a cheap way to communicate with many people.
With smart targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond. But they can never know exactly who will respond. Even the best direct mail doesn't get a 100 percent response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every client. With media, this can't happen. If advertisers knew who would respond, they wouldn't need media. They could contact people directly.
Any advertiser who gets one million new customers (2 percent of the adult population) is doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million extra customers. Any campaign that wins over 2 percent of the population is very successful. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message more carefully than before.

Title: Britain's Greenest Home
Charles Clover visits Britain's most environmentally-friendly home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This town has two surprises: the ancient Southwell Minster with its 'green' men carvings, and the 'autonomous house' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 
The Vales' house uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles sewage into garden compost, and heats the home with waste heat from appliances and body heat from the family and their two cats. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and fits well with the town's old buildings. It even got approval from planners in a conservation area.
The house is very quiet because it is super-insulated with special windows. Inside, it feels peaceful. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens windows and ventilation shafts to let in fresh air because the house is very draught-proof. Even the cats have their own special door.
The Vales, who teach architecture, have been interested in the environment for a long time. They wrote a book called "The Autonomous House" in the 1970s. They wanted to create a house that doesn't harm the environment. They designed it to not use mains water and to have no carbon dioxide emissions. They use rainwater tanks, special toilets, and copper gutters to keep the water clean. They don't use a dishwasher because they don't want to use strong detergents.
The house is not medieval, but it has a tall hall with a hearth and staircase. The Vales pay no water bills and use very little electricity. They plan to add solar panels to generate even more electricity, enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove, which they rarely use.
In winter, the house stays warm without much heating. Robert says the temperature feels comfortable because there are no draughts and everything is the same temperature. He suggests that people in old houses should live like people did in the past, but this idea might not be popular.
The house is simple and low-tech, with materials from local builders. It was cheap to build, costing the same as low-cost housing. However, commercial builders are not interested in this idea.

'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man, like a scientist. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies in a garden, he believed they were real proof that fairies existed. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural beings. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos admitted they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are very beautiful. But the simple trick shows that a basic idea about photography, that the camera cannot lie, is not true. Cameras can lie, and they always could. Today, we use computer software to change our digital photos, and it is not true that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the start, when cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

'Blacksmiths Iron has always been important to people, and blacksmiths, the people who work with iron, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The flowing metal designs of French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were also made by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s in Britain, blacksmiths were almost gone because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern buildings rarely used elegant wrought-iron designs. In the past 10 years, there has been a revival because people are more interested in decorative architecture and creative interior design. Still, much of the work looks old-fashioned, with gates and balconies often described as 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. Many design stores sell rusty candlesticks with decorations. Fortunately, there are new options, and events are being held to promote blacksmithing. One event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says we might be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently. Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld it easily. 'Now,' says Dawson, 'these artists can express themselves with metal.' About 250 pieces are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most money goes to the makers, but some supports good ironwork, says Dawson. His own works include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. 'My style comes from letting steel bend and flow when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space,' he says. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike other metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher. Susan May, a jeweler, says, 'It's magical because it's soft when hot but becomes hard when it cools.' Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles inspired by castles in horror films. One design looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. 'I love that steel is cold and hard,' she says. 'It feels like it will last forever.' Iron has given people visual pleasure and a sense of security. It will likely be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.'

Title: The Day I Quit Smoking
I thought everyone would be happy when I quit smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She said, "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't really explain how I went from smoking a pack a day to not smoking at all in just four hours. It even surprised me. 
I attended a stop-smoking session that combined group therapy and hypnotherapy. This happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to quit smoking, and I didn't really want to. I was annoyed by the pressure from people who were against smoking. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick and seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.
On a regular Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking in Birmingham to write an article about others trying to quit. I told them, "I won't try to stop myself because I'm here to write, not to quit." I thought I was being fair. I actually enjoyed smoking; it made me happy. The counselor seemed to understand something I didn't.
We were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't really want to, and neither did the others. The messages about quitting made sense to me. Just like smoking was a challenge because people were against it, quitting started to feel like a good idea. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling, just for me.
In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical craving for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and only lasted for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't a problem at all. I believed I needed nicotine to meet deadlines, but I was wrong. Surprisingly, spending weekend mornings at home was the hardest part, and it still is. I think smoking was a way to avoid boredom; having a cigarette was something to do.
Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each new experience as a non-smoker is different, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These were all times when I used to smoke.

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but not many people in Britain know her name. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's biography, has noticed this. When she tells people about her work, only a few recognize Hodgkin's name. 
Hodgkin was an amazing person. She won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. Later, in 1969, she also solved the structure of insulin. Her work was very important and difficult, but she also had a family. She had three children and a husband who was often away because he was a historian. 
In the past, scientific biographies were often boring and only focused on the scientist's work. They didn't talk much about their personal lives. But now, things are changing. Books about scientists like Richard Feynman, Isaac Newton, and Albert Einstein show their personal sides too. This makes them more interesting to readers.
Some people think scientists' lives are not as exciting as those of artists or writers. But this is not true. Scientists can have interesting lives too. For example, some scientists now appear on TV shows or in advertisements, which helps people see them as real people.
Understanding science can be challenging, but it's not harder than learning a new language or reading Shakespeare. It's important to know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin because they have made great contributions to our world.

Margaret and Her Special Skill
Margaret Wilkins has a special ability called a 'sixth sense'. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.
This skill, called dowsing, helps find water, minerals, and lost objects underground. People have different ideas about how it works. Some think it is about magnetism, while others think it is spiritual. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Dowsers, like Margaret, might be very good at feeling these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' or even smell water.
In recent years, there have been many droughts, so Margaret has been very busy. At one point, people had to wait almost six weeks for her help. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She also helps people with holiday homes far from water pipes and golf-course developers who need water for clubhouses.
Margaret looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. She makes sure the water is clean and not near any waste. The water she finds is in cracks of hard rock. It is important to have electricity nearby to run the water pump, so she tries to find water close to power supplies.
To start, Margaret uses a map and a pendulum on large areas like golf courses. She moves the pendulum over the map, and it swings when there is water below. Then, she walks over the land with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. The stick moves up when water is directly below. It is important to drill exactly where the stick shows, or they might miss the water.
Margaret's husband also checks the area with his stick. They usually agree on where to drill. If they don't agree, they keep looking until they do.
Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition. Many people are interested in how she does it. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This means she has a natural understanding of where water is. Without this skill, her family could not run their well-drilling business successfully.

**We changed lives for a day!**
Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different? We arranged this for four people. Read about their experiences.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant.
Amanda had never been in a place like the restaurant before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. She was not sure she would manage! Being a mother is busy, but this was different. She had only 15 minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but Amanda dropped the drinks, and they spilled everywhere. She was embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said everyone makes mistakes at first.
By 11:30 am, there was already a line of people waiting to get in, and Amanda felt nervous. She worried about remembering orders, but everything was automated, so it was not a problem. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she was not used to the loud music. She had to keep saying "Pardon?" to customers, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was very tired and wanted to soak her feet in hot water. She was surprised when a waitress said it had been a "quiet" day. Amanda realized waitressing is tiring and not as easy as she thought. She was glad to return to her children, which seemed easier after waitressing.
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy was nervous but excited to be a "mum" for the day. She knew the girls could be cheeky but thought she could handle it. She was wrong! After Amanda left for work, Cindy had to dress and feed the girls. She dropped Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, thinking she would have three hours of peace. But Amanda left a note with chores like making beds, cleaning, and doing laundry.
At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then home for lunch. When Sophie came home, the real trouble started. The girls turned the sofa into a trampoline and screamed loudly. Cindy thought they would get tired, but they didn't. She managed to get them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up and watch TV. Cindy found it exhausting to look after two small children. She didn't have a moment for herself, and the responsibility was overwhelming. Still, she enjoyed the day.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary, 30, a primary school teacher.
On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a treat. She worried about what to wear to school. At assembly, she hoped to blend in with the 400 pupils. In a maths class, children worked in groups, which was different from her school days. She helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired but found teachers only have five minutes to eat. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson and a French lesson, where children practiced on her rusty French. Finally, there was Physical Education. Rosemary was exhausted, but the children had lots of energy. She found speaking in front of the class hard. Even though teachers have more holidays, she prefers farming.
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, surprised that Rosemary had been up for three hours. The farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes. Rosemary also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream to sell. Hilary spent the morning in the ice cream parlour, bottling milk and packing ice cream. It was hard not to taste the treats!
At lunchtime, Hilary checked the sheep. She picked up a ewe that had fallen over because sheep can die if left for more than 12 hours. After feeding the calves, she started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year. Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children. The hardest part of farming is not being able to take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days' holiday a year. Farming seems romantic, but it is hard work, and the income is not steady.

'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, from southern Sweden, is one of them. At 30, he is a famous trumpet player, even though his parents were not musical. His records include both old and new music. When you meet him, he seems young and friendly, like the sound of his trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London, and a TV show talked about his work and life, filmed in both London and Sweden.
Hakan was born near Malmo. His career started because of a Christmas present when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved it and played all the time. His mother found a teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, who was a talented musician. Bo saw Hakan's natural talent and helped him a lot. Hakan is grateful for having such a good teacher who loved the trumpet and was always learning more about it.
Hakan explains that the trumpet is not a perfect instrument. Each trumpet has its own problems, and he learned to work with them. Even as a child, people could recognize his special sound. Unlike John Wallace, another famous trumpet player who started in brass bands, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired Maurice Andre, a French trumpeter, and collected all his records.
Hakan's parents supported his dream to become a professional trumpet player. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was too far and dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was not for him. Hakan knew he was good, but it was during a competition in Paris at 17 that he realized he could really connect with people through music. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and learned that people listened to him even if he made mistakes.
Hakan is realistic about his talent and doesn't try to explain why he can connect with people through music. He believes that the power of music is in its ability to move people.'

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special story about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is funny and shows the author's unique way of seeing things. It also gives deep insights into people's minds. The book is challenging but worth reading.
**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet someone like Sheila, who is from a working-class background. Sheila takes care of her old father and her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, on the street. After the court case, both boys do not want to talk about it. Leo, who was a good student and never fought before, does not explain why he did it. Joe gets better physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son and focuses all her time on him. Sheila feels very guilty and asks to meet Harriet. From this meeting, they start an unusual friendship. The author is good at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives. He also shows how mothers feel they can never do enough for their children.
**C.** This book was nominated for the Booker Prize. It tells the story of one of the most remote Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The story is mixed with important moments in Scottish history, imagined by the young main character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point but comes back after World War II, now understanding the simple lives of his ancestors.
**D.** After a big hit, the author wrote a sequel with the same gentle humor and sharp look at family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is almost seventy. She has a lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora is still charming, a bit vain, and kind. Rosie helps her as she enjoys managing her suitors and friends. By the end, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is taking over. The author is good at showing the hidden sadness in everyday life and how random events can be.
**E.** Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person learns about themselves during the trip. They return home with their spirits lifted by the experience of being on the ocean. The author uses surprising images to show themes of memory and awareness, which are both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and what a typical workday looks like.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34
**ANNE'S DAY**  
Anne wakes up at 6:30 am, goes to the gym at 7 am, and starts work by 8 am. She begins operating at 8:30 am. She operates all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most operations take three hours, but some can last all day. Sometimes, she works for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. She doesn't feel stressed while operating, but she worries about the next day's work. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it feels great. From 10 am to 1 pm, she talks to patients about their operations. She enjoys this part and finds it easy to talk to them. If patients get upset, she comforts them, but time can be tight. She leaves work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, she is on call and carries a beeper. On holidays, she worries about her patients for the first three days and dreams about operating at night. She finds it hard to relax.
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31
**MARITA'S DAY**  
Marita gets up at 7:45 am, leaves home by 8:20 am, takes the train, and arrives at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, her team meets to discuss their work and any problems. Her team has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only 10-15% of her work is designing; the rest is production. She gets a brief from the client and spends three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After presenting her ideas to the client and getting approval, she works on budgets and hires photographers and illustrators. She communicates with printers to ensure everything is on time. Managing people is a big part of her job. She has to communicate well with many people. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, and she tries to go out. If not, she eats sandwiches and works through lunch. It's a great feeling when a client likes her designs, but disappointing if the work is rejected. She gets home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later. She finds it hard to relax after work, especially when busy.
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42
**LINDA'S DAY**  
Linda usually gets up at 7 am, but on some days, she gets up between 4:30 am and 5 am to meet early flights. Around 10:30 or 11 am, she might go for a bike ride or swim. Since her job involves a lot of sitting, she watches her diet and exercises. She has a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask her for restaurant or shop recommendations, so she needs to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, so she can plan her routes. Not all passengers are polite; some are rude, but most are well-behaved. She has a good relationship with regular clients. Sometimes, she hears private conversations in the car and has to focus on driving. The press has tried to get her to talk about clients, but she doesn't. She works seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and tries to sleep by 11 pm.
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27
**TRACY'S DAY**  
Tracy gets up at 7 am, leaves home at 7:30 am, and starts her first job. She and her assistant maintain gardens they designed. They do some commercial work, but mostly private gardens. They spend about an hour and a half at each house. At 11 am, they have a big breakfast at a cafe. In summer, she may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. Her office is at home, so she checks messages and calls when she returns. If someone wants a garden designed, she meets them in the evening. They use old materials to make gardens look aged. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren't great, but it's satisfying to see a garden completed. It's hard to relax in the evening because she can hear the business phone. She sleeps well because the work is physical and tiring. The job is tough but allows creativity.
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27
**ZENA'S DAY**  
Zena arrives at the site by 8:30 am. She is an assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a wall to keep cars from driving into a quarry. She checks that contractors follow the schedule and safety rules. She helps solve problems and coordinates with site professionals. Contractors start at 6 am, so she first checks with the clerk of works about what happened since she left. Her day depends on this information. She reviews paperwork and answers design questions. Lunch is usually half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but she often eats on the go. When contractors are on break, it's easier to check the site. Checking their work can cause conflict, so she keeps communication open. She sees the duty resident engineer once a day but acts quickly if something important happens. She leaves the site around 6 pm and is always on call.

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes starting and managing the Membership Rewards program in big European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and answering emails. I handle all advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with our marketing team and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future projects. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to discuss issues. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone starts ringing at 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be helpful because it's important work for the artists. I know if the sound fits our record label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing and sales. I also manage budgets. I leave work at 7:00 pm at the earliest and often go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. I might visit an artist in the studio after a concert. My social life is mostly related to work. I often get home at 1:00 am and listen to a record to relax.
**C. Sales Director**
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client visits, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and selling furniture. We sell antiques priced from £1,000 to £6,000 and buy from various sources. Many items need restoration, so I work with restorers and repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while having coffee to stay updated on the business. I visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and take about an hour to relax.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work in shifts, and on early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. At 7:00 am, I take over from the night shift in the control tower. We have a rotating schedule, working for about an hour and a half at a station, then taking a break. We work as a team to control aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read up on new air traffic rules. It's important to be alert in this job, so I take sick leave if I'm not feeling well. The work is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and maybe a general manager of the airport.
**E. Shop Manager**
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by setting up the electronic sales system. I make sure someone is at the till and organize staff lunches and breaks. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be annoying when they expect me to gather many books for them. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' representatives visit to discuss new titles. I decide how many copies of a title to order. If we feature a new title, I ensure it's delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the system and locking up before going home.
**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies abroad, warning clients of potential problems. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first preview is due by 10:00 am, and the second by 11:00 am, so I work quickly. I type stories, send them to my editor, and make changes before they are published. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but it's hard to relax, and I'm often awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: How to Be a Good Leader at Work**
A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader is someone who inspires others and helps bring change. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says leadership is about making things happen with people who are as excited as you are. Enthusiasm is important, and a good leader should speak clearly and confidently. Dixon says it's better to say "I believe" than "I think."
B. **Everyone Can Be a Leader**  
John van Maurik, who teaches leadership, says many people have the potential to be leaders. We just need the right situation to show it. We often see leaders as famous people like Mahatma Gandhi or Richard Branson, but leadership is also important in our own workplaces.
C. **Think About Your Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. They might both be good at meeting goals, but how did they do it? A good leader motivates and supports you. A bad leader makes you feel unimportant and blames you when things go wrong.
D. **Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new paths. A good manager can keep things running, but a good leader can change a struggling company or team.
E. **Improve Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you're the boss or not, you can learn to be a better leader. Here are some tips:
- Find what you are passionate about and use that energy to lead.
- Think of yourself as a leader. Believe in your ability to lead.
- Sometimes you need to be firm. Try different leadership styles and see what works.
- Set goals and try to beat them. Look at your job and see where leadership can help you succeed.
F. **Developing Leadership**  
- Leadership takes practice. Take risks and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, and praise others.
- Your way of leading might not work for everyone. Keep improving your communication skills.
- Be visible and available to those who matter. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know when your leadership is needed and help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**
**A. Abyss**  
Before making Titanic, director James Cameron created this intense Cold War thriller. It’s about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team remind us of heroes from old movies. The special effects are amazing, but the story and dialogue are not very strong. Despite the great filmmaking, the story feels like a simple B-movie.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This version of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal is directed by Andrew Marton. It is different from Terrence Malick's new film. Marton’s movie is a traditional war film, focusing on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick’s film is more complex, but Marton’s has its good moments. A flashback scene where the soldier dreams of his wife is very powerful.
**C. On Guard**  
Based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, this entertaining adventure is better than most musketeer films. Fabrice Luchini plays a great villain, and Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short. Daniel Auteuil is a bit serious for this fun film, but he still shines as a swordsman. The film uses classic costume-drama ideas with humor and energy.
**D. Character**  
Set in early 1900s Rotterdam, this film looks like a museum piece due to its detailed design. Jan Decleir plays Dreverhaven, a harsh bailiff who evicts tenants. The story focuses on his difficult relationship with his son. However, the filmmakers seem more interested in showing the period details than exploring the story’s dark themes.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released video highlights director Leone's skills. The sound is excellent, making every noise clear. The story is harsh, and the music by Morricone adds excitement. Morally, the characters (Clint Eastwood, Lee van Cleef, and Eli Wallach) are all equally ruthless as they travel across the post-Civil War West.
**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war epic boasts "forty-eight international stars." With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, are slow. While impressive in scale, it’s better suited for the big screen. On video, it loses some of its impact.

**BOOK A**  
"Compelling Evidence" by Steve Martin is a very interesting book. The story is about a lawyer who starts a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife, who is accused of killing her husband. The trial is exciting, and the ending is surprising. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" starts with excitement. Sigismondo, a problem-solver for rich people in the Italian Renaissance, gets involved in politics and murder. We know he will find the guilty people. The story is complex and a bit long, but still very enjoyable.
**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter, a tax inspector, becomes a detective when a man dies near her. She faces challenges and disapproval from a local detective, but she is strong and successful. Leah is a great new character.
**BOOK D**  
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk to remove drug dealers from a poor area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, with more thinking than violence. Parker delivers high-quality entertainment.
**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann has detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate a burglary and attack at a famous actress's daughter's house. The author's easy style and interesting look at human behavior make this a fun mystery.
**BOOK F**  
"Blood Red, Snow White" is written by Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features a lawyer and a female client, but the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book mixes romance, money, and violence well, creating a gripping suspense novel.
**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw stars actor Philip Fletcher, who is now a target. A funny group of characters come together to film Robin Hood, but Philip is unhappy with his career. Shaw usually entertains, but this time the story is not as strong as usual.
**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" by Lawrence Gough is his best book in a while. Canadian police chase a smart bank robber who targets female bank workers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the clever, troubled robber, making it better than the average detective novel.

"I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age decide to take this big step. This summer, I quit my job, decided to rent out my apartment, and travel in Southeast Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old, and I'm nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking around North and South America. When I came back, I wanted to do it again someday. But then, I fell in love, started a career, bought an apartment, and got used to earning money. I realized I was giving up my happiness for my salary. When I quit my job, it felt like I was in control of my life again. Now, I have no ties. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn't change places with me, they envy my freedom. I'm not in a relationship, and I don't have big career goals. I feel like I should enjoy this freedom, even for my friends' sake! Why am I nervous? First, it's about making the necessary plans. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I need to decide where to go. I'm bad at making decisions and am already weeks behind my plan. 'Might as well enjoy the summer in England,' I told myself. Then, 'Why not stay for the start of the football season?' Leaving emotional ties makes it harder. I'm delaying because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I adjust to a simpler life? Will I fit in with young backpackers? Maybe not. I've found that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to leave their lives and travel. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet guidebooks, says people realize they can have adventures if they're brave, organized, and confident. For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, it's a chance to have fun before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I'm ready to give up job security for the trip,' says Danny. 'There's always a worry that I'm not moving up in my career, but it's a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a sign of defiance!' For Matt, who just left the Army, a year of traveling was a time of change. 'In the military, there's a set way of doing things. I needed to change this to live well as a civilian.' There are many reasons to travel at my age, but some common factors exist. 'We have a more flexible workforce today,' says Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development. 'More people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.' Big companies even have career-break policies. 'If you've trained someone, it's good to know they'll come back rather than work for a competitor.' Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that shares stories of 'ordinary' travelers, says more people in their thirties are rethinking their lives. 'If you're not happy with your job, it's not about just sticking with it. Now people know there are opportunities, and a job isn't "for life" anymore. Travel lets you reassess and think about your life.' Is wanting to travel just a sign that my generation can't handle adulthood? Jennifer Cox thinks not. 'It's a sign of a better-educated, more stable society when we're less worried about paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We're asking, "Is this what I want?"' Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn't think he's running away. 'It's more about running towards something. It's trying to get things I want for myself.' But he feels some fear. 'It's the thought of leaving behind a comfortable routine - going to the office every day, saying "hi" to everyone, and having a coffee.' I share Ben's worries about leaving a stable life, and I'm not sure I'd be traveling if I didn't find my boss so difficult. As Jennifer Cox says, 'This is common. There's often a reason, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to go.' It might have taken a push to get me moving, but I'm now excited about the next 12 months. Whatever happens, I'll be happy I took this chance. And I think all of us older backpackers feel the same."

'Plugging in the home Georgina McGuiness had taken a long break from her job in journalism and felt out of touch with new technology. She shares how she turned her family home into a good place to work. The Christmas before last, when I turned 37, I realized I needed to restart my journalism career. My skills were outdated, stuck in the 1980s when typewriters were the best technology. I felt like no one would hire me because I didn't know how to use computers or desktop publishing. I was afraid of technology; even simple things like calculators confused me. I knew I had to change quickly. I thought it would be hard to go back to work before my kids grew up, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. Amazingly, my family won a computer package. We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We started learning about the Internet and new words like cyberspace and surfing. We began chatting with people around the world online. The kids stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem to connect to the Internet. I could work from home and still take the kids to school. The kids were comfortable with computers because they used them at school. I was nervous, thinking I might lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. But I learned the basics, and it was easier than I thought. I started writing articles for a magazine and felt happy to have the best of both worlds. The computer helped me become organized. I used spreadsheets to track money and pre-made invoices and letterheads to save time. Being online helped me research stories and talk to other journalists. But working from home can be lonely, and there are distractions like house chores. When the kids are home, we sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. Many people are buying computers for education and fun. In my neighborhood, more people are working from home because it's easier than commuting to the city. A report on computer use in UK homes says the average user is 38 years old and well-educated. Most have a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. I feel like I'm ahead of the game. Maybe one day I'll send a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even start my own magazine from home. It seems the possibilities are endless.'

The Tartan Museum
The new Museum of Scotland in Edinburgh has modern buildings that look very different from the old city around them. Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened to see if the inside was as interesting as the outside.
The museum is easy to find because of its big, yellow sandstone tower and unique shape. Last winter, people had mixed feelings about the building's design. Some loved it, calling it a 'masterpiece', while others were not so sure. Now, as the museum is about to open, people are wondering if the exhibitions inside will be just as interesting.
The museum tells many stories about Scotland's history, using important objects like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels. It helps visitors understand the timeline of events without being too strict. The museum does not let national pride overshadow the beauty of its treasures.
Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of the exhibitions, wants the museum to be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. He believes in showing the truth about history, so there are no fake scenes or imagined stories. Instead, the museum uses explanation panels, captions, and some computers to tell the stories of the objects.
Inside the museum, the spaces are open and bright, with walls that look like stone and display cases. There is plenty of room to look at each item. The museum also has a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of young advisors from all over Scotland. They wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a special hands-on area for kids.
On the top floor, there is a gallery about the Twentieth Century. It shows objects that people in Scotland think were important in the last century, like electric guitars and televisions. This part of the museum will change every three years.
Dr. Clarke believes that objects help us understand the past better than anything else. The modern design of the museum works well inside, but some people wonder if it fits with the old city around it.

The end of print newspapers might take a long time. Change can be scary for some people, but the word "transition" sounds nicer. It means moving smoothly from the present to the future. However, the move from print newspapers to online news is not smooth. Many people think it will happen because print sales are going down while visits to newspaper websites are going up. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% in a year, but their website visits are increasing.
But the situation is not the same everywhere. The World Association of Newspapers says that global newspaper circulation actually went up by 1.1% last year, thanks to Asia. In the West, sales went down, but in Asia, they went up. News magazines also saw a 5.4% increase. Books are another example. E-readers like Kindle are selling well, but physical book sales only went down by 0.4%.
Young people are still reading newspapers. Nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 read the main national newspapers. In Europe, the situation is different in each country. In Britain, print sales dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop was only 7%, and in France, it was 3.1%.
In the past, people thought online ads would make online newspapers successful. But now, online ad revenue is going down. Many US newspapers have started charging for online content. The best way to get people to pay is to offer both print and digital access together. Print is still important for selling online subscriptions, and print ads make more money than online ads.
This is not easy for newspaper companies because running both print and online editions is expensive. But print still helps newspapers stay well-known, while online, it is harder to get noticed.

**Photographing People**
People are very interesting to photograph. A picture with a person is usually more interesting than one without. But taking good photos of people can be hard. You need to think about how they move and their facial expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.
**A. Grouping People**
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all faces. You can also take the photo from a higher position.
**B. Posing for Pictures**
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting they fold their hands or put them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**
Don't pretend you are not taking a picture. This can make people uncomfortable. Most people will agree to be photographed, but they might feel self-conscious. You may need to guide them. Make sure they are not looking away from the camera.
**D. Eye Contact**
A photo is more powerful if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They don't have to smile. Remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**
Instead of looking at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural. Candid shots are interesting, and the person's expression is important.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**
Expressions and gestures tell a lot about a person. A laughing child makes us smile, while a sad face makes us feel sympathy. Look for familiar expressions like winks, anger, or thumbs-up. They are easy to understand.
**G. Situation Interest**
A person's background can add interest to a photo. Make sure the background is not too busy. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person stand out more.
**H. Interaction**
When people are talking or working together, there are chances for good photos. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Capture how one person reacts to another.
**I. People and Places**
Many photos are taken on holidays to show where people have been. Use a wide-angle lens to include the background. Ask people to stand close to the camera. A good photo shows both the people and the place equally.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**
Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose. But family photos can be more fun if they are not posed. Candid photos capture real moments and are more memorable.

**Under Sarah's Spell**
Sarah Janson is an artist who creates trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings trick the eye into seeing something that looks real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about Sarah and her work.
Sarah Janson is different from many artists because she doesn't sign her paintings unless someone asks her to. She believes the art is more important than the artist. Sarah is very humble and sometimes acts like her paintings create themselves. This makes her a bit shy during interviews. She doesn't like talking about herself and feels uncomfortable being photographed.
After some time, Sarah becomes more relaxed, and the interview turns into a fun and interesting conversation. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she wasn't happy with illustration, so she started working with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create a trompe-l'oeil, and she loved it. She decided to start her own business, even though she wasn't sure where it would lead.
Sarah's skills in observing and focusing on details, which she learned from illustrating, are very important for her trompe-l'oeil work. She says that no one can teach you trompe-l'oeil; it's all about observing life. She believes that you should always keep learning and never think you know everything.
Sarah is honest about her weaknesses. For example, she says she can't paint bread well. She also had trouble with math when working on a big project for a chapel ceiling. She often questions herself and talks about her work as if someone else did it.
Sarah's trompe-l'oeil art is very special and stands out from others. Her work is often inspired by architecture. For example, she painted a dining room to look like a Venetian palace and created a painting that makes a hallway look like it leads to more rooms.
Trompe-l'oeil art needs to do two things: it must trick you and then keep your interest. Sarah believes it should also be personal to the client. She enjoys working with clients and getting ideas from them. Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working.
Sarah appreciates her clients and is thankful for those who trust her with their walls. Even though she doesn't like to talk about her talent, her clients are very happy with her work, and she is always busy. Sarah says she doesn't want her work to shout for attention because people get bored with things that shout. But her work is so interesting that you could never get bored with it. It deserves to be more well-known, even if she doesn't like to brag about it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
**A** The way we work is changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or our skills, but also by how we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging people helps decide who gets hired or promoted. It shows who might become a top performer and who might not. These skills are important for future jobs, no matter what field we work in. Doing well in exams is not as important as we thought. Instead, social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness are important. These are called emotional intelligence.
**B** Today, job security is not guaranteed, and the idea of a 'job' is changing to 'portable skills'. Personal qualities are becoming important at work. Emotional intelligence is the ability to understand and manage our own and others' feelings. It includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some people think it means just 'being nice', but sometimes it means telling the truth even if it's hard. It doesn't mean showing all your feelings, but managing them well so people can work together towards a common goal.
**C** More businesses see that emotional intelligence is important for management. The more complex the job, the more emotional intelligence matters. Some people succeed even with low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more team-based, companies where people work well together have an advantage. In today's workplace, teamwork and customer focus make emotional intelligence essential for success everywhere.
**D** Unlike IQ, which changes little, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. Studies show people get better at handling emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others. This growth is called maturity. Emotional intelligence can be learned, and we can add these skills to help us succeed. This is important when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but ignoring it can make everything else less effective.

'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to take pictures of important events. Social media has changed how people share these photos. Now, news often appears first on social networks, and some journalists use these images for their stories. Sometimes, reporters use photos from social media without asking for permission. There are rules that say images can be used without permission if there is a very important reason, but people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take a photo or video of a news event. This means that user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. However, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure people are paid for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West: Acupuncture**
**What is Acupuncture?**
Acupuncture is a part of ancient Chinese medicine, which is about 2,000 years old. It includes using herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is mainly known in the West for helping with pain. Some doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists use it to help people feel less pain.
**How Does It Work?**
In traditional Chinese medicine, health means the energy of the mind, body, and spirit is balanced. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), moves through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an organ. If Qi is blocked or weak, it can cause illness. An acupuncturist checks your wrist pulse, looks at your tongue, and asks about your health and habits to find where Qi is unbalanced. They use thin needles on the skin to help Qi flow better. Sometimes, they also use heat or pressure.
**Acupuncture Points**
There are over 300 points on the main meridians where needles can be placed. These points might not be near where you feel pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This feeling means the needle has reached the Qi.
**Scientific View**
Even without believing in traditional Chinese ideas, some doctors agree that acupuncture can help with pain. They think it might work by blocking pain signals to the brain or by releasing natural painkillers in the body.
**Types of Pain Treated**
People with long-term pain often try acupuncture. It is used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in very sick people.
**Modern Use**
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia in surgery started in the 1950s. This showed some doctors outside China that acupuncture could be more than just a mental effect. In China, it is used in many surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs. It is said to reduce pain without the side effects of regular anesthesia, like feeling sick.
**Effectiveness**
It is hard to test acupuncture in clinical trials, but some studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with chronic pain. Acupuncturists say it usually takes six or seven visits to feel real relief, but some improvement should be felt after two or three visits.
**Different Views on Pain**
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the symptoms. They spend time finding out what might be causing the pain, like weather conditions or the type of pain. This is different from how most doctors work.
**Choosing an Acupuncturist**
Some medical professionals are trained in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe their methods can lead to longer-lasting cures. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist who will refer you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems very confident, like she could be the head of a girls' school, but she is actually quite shy. She says that her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is a bit like her, or how she might have been if she were a man. Both she and her character like to solve problems alone. She needs privacy to write and can work anywhere as long as she is alone.
P.D. James is very humble and doesn't agree when people say she is Britain's most famous crime writer, even though millions of people read her 12 detective novels. She enjoys reading books by her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. She also likes books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she reads male authors too, like Graham Greene.
P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, "Cover Her Face," was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge, where she met her husband, Connor Bantry White. Life was difficult for her because her husband came back from World War II very sick. She had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped by taking care of the children.
She worked full-time for the National Health Service and later for the Home Office, dealing with police and crime. She got used to seeing dead bodies while working in forensic science, but she was more interested in writing crime stories. She liked the challenge of creating a story and always wanted to be a writer. Writing detective stories was a way for her to bring order to chaos and to write about people in a serious way. She believes solving a crime in a story shows that life is important, even if the person is not well-liked. She says nobody really likes violence.

Title: Handwriting Analysis: A Growing Interest
In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This is because handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is considered important in deciding if you are right for the job. Many people believe that graphology is a real science. They say it can help identify illnesses like heart disease and cancer, and it can show a person's psychological state and emotions.
Graphology is being used more and more for career guidance and during job interviews. Many large companies hire graphologists to study the handwriting of people applying for important jobs. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are not convinced about the value of graphology.
Patricia Marne, who has been a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks that doctors should take graphology more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. According to her, handwriting can indicate social class, intelligence, mental ability, and whether a person is more suited to arts or sciences. It can also show if someone has a devious or open character.
Ms. Marne says graphology can be useful in identifying criminal tendencies. She claims that criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is usually poorly shaped. She believes that many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional issues, which can be seen in their handwriting. For example, young male offenders often have high ascenders in their writing, suggesting they live in a world of fantasy.
Graphologists can also tell if someone is under a lot of pressure or has violent tendencies. Handwriting might even predict if someone is at risk of suicide. Health problems, like heart and lung issues, can also appear in handwriting. If a person's writing changes over time or becomes shaky, it might mean something serious has happened.
