She enjoys working when she wants, but her business requires her to take calls at odd hours because most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America. The challenge is to stop working and close the office door. She publishes children's books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. At first, she felt lonely because all her experience was in London.
**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop. She started ten years ago at home, making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. Friends and family began requesting her cakes, and soon she was sending them all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made. She has a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg now manages the business side and doesn't bake anymore. Her biggest challenge has been managing the finances because she didn't have a lot of money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons, Paul and Huw, are talented musicians and composers, and their father, John, makes musical instruments.
When Paul was ten years old, his parents, John and Hetty, wanted to buy him a cello because he was getting very good at playing. However, cellos were very expensive. John decided to try making one himself. He found a school nearby that taught instrument making and took evening classes for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he made his first cello for Paul. It turned out well, and Paul used it for many years.
John enjoyed making instruments so much that he retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman. He now makes about twelve violins a year. One of his violins was even bought by a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.
Both Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano and then became interested in the cello. He was inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, on the other hand, chose to play the piano and compose music.
Paul achieved great success with the cello his father made. He won a big music competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. Recently, he started playing a very old and valuable cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is on loan to him.
Paul will soon be on television playing this new cello in a famous piece, Elgar's Cello Concerto. However, he won't be able to watch himself because he will be performing at a festival that night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will be performed in London for the first time.
John and Hetty are very proud of their sons and will have to work hard to keep up with all their musical events.

'Looking after the countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that works to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and must be good with people because they often work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people wanted the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula, but Gareth got it because he knew the area well and had farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. He still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. His farming background also helps him with the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and building walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and realizes now that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it's not the farmers' fault because they were following government advice. When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists disagreed, but now they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's work includes conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He makes sure jobs are done efficiently and enjoys seeing projects completed, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork. Gareth loves his job, even though he is always on duty, and enjoys talking to most of the public. However, he dislikes when some people act entitled. If you have common sense and like outdoor work, you might consider becoming a warden like Gareth, but don't expect a job on the Lleyn Peninsula to open up soon!'

'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked her. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all.' 'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. 'I have a strict schedule to get as fit as possible.' These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries taking part. 'We'll have support from people at home, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start with a good game.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of skill.' The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra says, the World Championships will be hard. 'You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, there's only one chance, and you have to be ready.' In the fifteen years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the final whistle, we are all friendlier.' Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and must lead by example. I support and encourage the team.' 'From the start, my netball career was carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player.' She will probably coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**
What should you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them grow their talent. Some parents might not notice their child's musical needs until the child becomes upset or difficult. Regular schools are usually good at helping children who are smart in subjects like math or science, but musically talented children need special care that regular schools might not offer. 
Specialist music schools can be a good choice for these children. In Britain, there are five such schools. They help children aged seven to eighteen to improve their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music. They have individual lessons, play in orchestras, learn about singing, conducting, and music theory. They also practice for several hours each day. The rest of their time is spent on important subjects like English, math, science, and languages. 
These schools are private, and classes are small with more teachers for each student. Most students live at the school, which means they spend a lot of time with other children who also love music. 
There are some downsides. The schools are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for students who live there. However, schools try to help parents with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want their young children to live away from home. School directors worry about admitting very young children because the environment is intense. They want to make sure children grow up to be well-rounded individuals. 
Being in a special music school can be stressful. Some children might lose interest in music as they grow older, and the pressure to succeed can be hard. Schools watch their students closely and offer help if needed. Many students enjoy the high-quality music teaching, but some feel that the academic subjects are not given enough attention. 
Musically talented children are often smart in other areas too. They might feel unhappy if their academic needs are not met. It might be better to wait until the child is older and can decide for themselves if they want to go to a specialist school. Children who are good at both music and academics might do well in a regular school with a strong music program. They can also take music lessons at music colleges on weekends. However, this might not be possible for families who live far from big cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her house has a big garden with many flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread everywhere. The garden has a nice mix of colors and shapes, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening. They left plants that Susan likes, and she also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny didn't agree with some of her ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.
Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She says, "I don't set the whole thing up at once." She paints one flower at a time, which can take a few days, and then adds more flowers. Sometimes, it takes a couple of years to finish a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they age very interesting. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being in water for a day.
Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers back then because they looked fake to her. She was amazed by how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rocks or cliffs. Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places like China and the Himalayas, but they grow well in her garden too. She is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.
Susan is busy with two upcoming exhibitions and has a lot of flowers to paint. She finds it hard to find time to work in the garden, so she hired another gardener. But she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Title: Keeping Holiday Guests Happy
Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year doing this job. Sarah, also called Pilch, cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets. Chalets are wooden houses typical of the area. Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more settled life. 'It's a good way to meet successful people,' she says.
Sarah does not live at the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then prepares breakfast for the guests. They get a full breakfast with porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning is the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. She tries to ski as much as she can. 'On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.'
Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower but does not nap because it makes her too tired. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and loads the dishwasher. 'I don't like coming to a messy kitchen in the morning,' she says. Sometimes she talks with the guests, and other times they prefer to be alone. 'Good guests can make the week great, but some weeks are not as good,' she says.
Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives and they go out around 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. But she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'It's a tough day,' she says, 'and you don't want to be tired when cooking breakfast.' On Sunday, work starts earlier because breakfast must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet quickly. 'We clean everything - clear breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for new guests.' If she hasn't shopped on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., cleaning is done, and she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. 'I think the mountain air affects them,' she says.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment and gets a ride back to the chalet. Then it's time for dinner again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early,' she says.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**
Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't like that. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I usually clean cages or handle rats. I find magazines interesting, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there."
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa."
Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I didn't know landscape gardening was so hard and needed careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job."
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint, but I was okay. The nurses' friendship is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't pleasant, but it was satisfying."
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and people suddenly respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from fitness training. On the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one adult."
Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer. "I was worried because I don't exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch that some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they drank lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this, but it inspired me to join a gym and be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**
**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France and visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and into Italy. The views of the sea are amazing, no matter the weather or time of year. On the other side, you can see beautiful gardens and homes. It feels like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The people on the train are always interesting, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the beautiful journey.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have taken many train trips, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to the Kruger National Park because I was too young and had to stay with an aunt. When I moved to England as a teenager, I had never been on a train. London Waterloo was the first big station I saw, and its glass dome amazed me.
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor was the perfect way to relax after our wedding.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable, and the driver would wait for people to arrive before leaving. When the train came, many people climbed on, even on the roof for free. At night, the train passed through beautiful landscapes, like a dream, as if we were traveling on the moon.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people love trains from childhood, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw few trains. As a teenager, I made a film in Yorkshire with a railway. The filming was on an old train line kept by volunteers. That's when I started loving steam trains. We rode the train whenever we could, and when I returned last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

'Want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, has advice for you. Many readers ask, 'I wrote a story/book. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to research publishers and improve your writing skills. Selling your writing requires knowing the 'writing game'. Whatever you write, learn about the markets you want to target. The best way is to read a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely helps you understand what publishers want. Keep updating your knowledge because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always look for new writers, so give them what they want. If you want to write short love stories, find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and learn what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. Editors focus on what their readers want. Writers often ask me, 'My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?' As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone. But if your work isn't ready, it might not be published. Most new writers send their work too soon. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Each one will be better, and you'll gain confidence. Don't throw any away—improve them. I suggest not showing your work to others at first. Remember, every successful writer faced many rejections. Do everything to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course or join a local writers' group to get ideas and confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was busier than usual. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. A well-dressed, grey-haired man was talking to different people. He asked a woman sitting alone and then a girl near me if they were going to Philadelphia. The girl said she was going to New York. The man thanked her and moved on. 
I was curious about him. He asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said Wilmington. He didn't say anything and moved on to another couple. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. Maybe I looked unreliable to him. He seemed stressed and asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia. She said yes. 
The man asked her for a favor. I pretended to check my watch, even though I didn't have one. The woman seemed cautious. The man explained that his daughter was flying abroad from Philadelphia and had forgotten her passport. She called home from the station, not knowing what to do. He told her to stay there, and he would find someone to bring her passport. 
The woman asked why he didn't go himself. He said he couldn't leave his wife alone because she was in a wheelchair. This seemed like a weak excuse to me. The man was holding a padded envelope, which seemed suspicious. I silently warned the woman to be careful.

**Gary and Me**
John Moore, a restaurant owner, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef.
I think everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was just what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory, and I was upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife took care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This was very good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.
Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he had a talent for it. So when he told me, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for school,' I sent him to a friend who has a restaurant.
Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do well. I told him, 'Gary, if you want to achieve something in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it might be too late.'
Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping other people. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm very proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one gives you anything for free. He saw the opportunity he was given and took it with both hands. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even a little of what you told them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.

Finding a good apartment in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult, like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place is through personal connections: if you know someone who knows someone leaving a place, that often helps. But if you are new to Dublin, like Jo, you don't have any personal contacts to tell you about available places. So, you have to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going to Dublin. Everyone at her school assumed she would go. Who would want to stay in a small, boring town? That's what she heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, see some life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle. But no one from Jo's year was going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently because it was run by nuns, and she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn't know they were all thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The fact that it said "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who was obviously not chosen, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued climbing. "Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, which amazed Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one. "I'm Jo, I work in the post office, and I called about the flat." Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said "Nessa," one said "Pauline," and the other said "Other." "We'll put your name on it if you stay," she said kindly.

'Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We like to see them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are disappearing. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows don't show the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think dolphins are protected by law and live in safe areas, but this is not true. Without plans to help them, dolphins might face a big disaster. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. The first two live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups. We don't know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only in Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few left have skin injuries, showing they are stressed. Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to know why their numbers are falling. Overfishing is a big problem. It reduces fish stocks and threatens dolphins because they need to find food quickly. If fish are gone, dolphins might not survive. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they can't see. Modern fishing uses big nets that float or move fast in the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornwall beaches, showing they died from getting caught in nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them. These poisons can pass to their young through milk. There is a case where a young dolphin died from its mother's milk. Another big threat to dolphins is human noise. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. Noise from ships and oil wells travels well in water and might disturb dolphins in ways we don't know yet.'

**Getting Fit**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels busy and stressful. You might think this is just another article about fitness, but exercise is really good for you. There are many reasons to exercise and not many reasons not to.
Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps you stand or sit with good posture, which is how you hold your body. Good posture prevents muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise also helps your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.
You might have heard these reasons before and feel bored, but here are some more. Exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems. It also helps control stress and can improve some medical conditions. Common sense should tell you that exercise is good for you.
There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or lifting weights. Be careful not to train too hard or with too much weight, as this can cause injuries. Start slowly and carefully. If you are unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.
Good posture is important for how you look and feel. A stiff or slouching body can be unattractive and have less energy. If you slouch, imagine a balloon pulling your head up to the sky. This helps you stand taller and breathe better. It also makes your body look slimmer.
Stretching your muscles makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine and should be done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

'IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest people to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained almost non-stop for six months, causing many problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive tool so that when their vehicle gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him out. Their teamwork has created some of TV's best wildlife films, like their popular film on leopards. Even while this film was being shown, they were already back in Africa, this time following the shy jackal. This is common for TV partnerships. Travelling film-makers have been going around the world to film exotic wildlife since TV began. I talked to Newman about their partnership while he was visiting a safari lodge. 'We sometimes argue but we get over it quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither of them is the leader, and they get along well because they see animals in the same way. 'When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now we have a fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each morning, we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem,' says Newman. It can be tough, but being alone in remote areas lets them get close to animals. Newman remembers filming a lion family where one lioness would greet their car as part of her routine. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift', and two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. Since then, they spend four months on location for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I have a good working relationship because we share the same ideas and vision,' says Newman. 'We want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals and touch people's hearts. I believe it's better to make people feel something than just think about it.'

'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slawinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a typical day for the weeks before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.' 'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. I'm on a strict schedule to get very fit for them. These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries taking part. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start well.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. We have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of skill.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra says, the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance, and you have to be ready.' In the fifteen years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. But after the game, we are all friendlier.' Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. I support and encourage the team.' 'From the start, my netball career was carefully planned,' she says. So I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player. She will probably coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.'

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, teaching and researching marine geochemistry, which is the study of chemical processes in the sea. When she is not teaching, she goes on dives in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can touch the two pilots. They can't stand or move much and must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.
If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it might not be a pleasant experience.
Rachel has made six dives so far. Last year, she dived with a Russian team to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, are many underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a hole 150 meters through a volcano.
When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke, pouring out at one meter per second and at 350 degrees.
Rachel was scared once when diving with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a loud explosion. She thought she might die, but nothing happened, and they were relieved to be safe.
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she sees the chimneys through the porthole, she feels a sense of wonder. She studied black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., and seeing them in real life was an amazing experience.

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people decide what they think about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, our volume and tone of voice, and the words we use.
Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should try to look your best." Many people forget how important it is to have a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but didn't even get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."
Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job right away. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't say no. So, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I'm sure I could have got more if I had controlled my excitement."
Finally, what we say and how we say it is important for a successful interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company's work. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confused sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring and not fun anymore. He didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but he lost his job unexpectedly. He didn't get much money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. His big chance came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat by mail order. He is happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works 80 to 90 hours a week and sells a product.
**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him, and he was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work for money. Ron and his family moved to the north of England, where they didn't know anyone. They left their friends, but their friendships survived, and many friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison was a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were long. She didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she never did. Her business is related to fashion, so there are always deadlines and new collections to work on. She feels happier and less stressed now. She misses socializing with colleagues but loves being responsible for her product. If something goes wrong, it's her responsibility.
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in financial markets at 22, making deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took massage courses. He got a part-time job at the Life Centre and has no regrets. He feels in control of his life now and has peace of mind.

'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I've always loved sports. I tried many different ones, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose to focus on running instead. My biggest moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because there are great facilities and nightlife there. But I have to be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to get to the next Olympics - that would be amazing. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you can't go to late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I do love sleeping in, which I have to give up too. It's worth it because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I make sure to have a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship got me a TV show about surfing. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly when we're out, but we don't look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about where we celebrate than how we did in the race. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come back and hang out with friends who do different things. You can't focus on the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I've only been recognized in the street a few times. I'd hate to be a celebrity. I get nice letters from people asking for signed pictures, and I reply to every one. It takes time, but it's worth it. D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to walk on the court and feel the crowd's support. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. I still enjoy being noticed by fans when I'm out shopping. But it has downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up, I think. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me too much. I'm happy to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, because retirement comes early in this sport.'

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sugary breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't afford all this stuff, and I feel guilty about buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset even before we leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and they find it hard to believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when they see fun and exciting ads.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children all the time."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' that's still what they want."
Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy for their children and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads, so they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad for him, but we buy chocolate and cream for ourselves. It's nice to buy good things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm in a good mood, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.

'Luxury and Modern Technology at the Merrion Hotel The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four big old houses into this new hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, like what guests like, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. The system cost £250,000, but MacCann believes it will be worth it. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them next time. This is because of the guest-history feature, where staff can save guest preferences. Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little themselves, or the front desk can adjust it more. Business guests will like the technology in their rooms. MacCann thinks 65% of the hotel's business will come from business travelers. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing tool. Technology changes fast, so the hotel has prepared for future updates. Extra cables are ready for new technology. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be replaced easily. DVD players can also be updated. Even with all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food at the hotel must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This is good for both him and the hotel. He got to design a new kitchen and has better parking. The hotel gets a popular restaurant without financial risk. With technology and a great staff, the Merrion is likely to do well.'

**Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share how they do it.
**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
"I get energy from excitement. I need to do things that challenge me. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. I also get energy from rhythm, like when I learn flamenco dancing. Dance is great because it's expressive and gives you energy. If you're bored, you might feel tired. Doing something useful, even if it's small, gives you energy."
**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel hard. If you like what you do, you don't feel down, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep to feel good. When I only get six hours of sleep, I feel tired. Exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start. I do yoga once a week and try to exercise at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I feel tired in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon, so I think it's good to eat something then."
**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't eat healthily for energy; I think it's my natural enthusiasm and being positive. I don't like negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and live in the moment. Enjoyment is important. I set goals and enjoy my work. The last two years have been exciting. I work with lively young people, which is energizing. I love being busy and social. I enjoy taking photos and writing imaginary song lyrics for fun. It helps me relax when I travel."
**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and family life. Being positive helps. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Energy is like a natural chemical that comes from talking to others. Smiling at people and getting a smile back feels great. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise plan. I get my exercise by playing with kids."
**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
"I love making a garden from a wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a garden by breaking the concrete and adding soil. It was better than any workout. I also get energy from knowing people want to read my writing. I find it hard to write if no one is interested. I like exploring places like farms or woods. If someone finds me, I say, 'Oh, I didn't know it was private.' It's fun and makes me feel like a child."
**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
"I believe you should be interested in and respect what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't like makes you tired. I used to be on committees and didn't like the time they took. You only have so much energy, so use it for things that matter to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until about 200 AD when iron skates came to Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, the upper classes thought skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was more about style, but in the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie made it more athletic. This made skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both beautiful and physically challenging.
For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can go faster as you get better. Your body position helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to keep your weight centered. Your body should lean a little forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It’s quite easy, right? As you practice, you can make your movements longer.
Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for skaters. Even the best skaters fall. To avoid injury, try to be relaxed when you fall. This helps reduce the shock of hitting the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand.
Once you can skate confidently, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer lessons to help you learn the basic moves, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.
Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, you should do regular exercises. It’s dangerous to skate with a stiff body, so warm-up exercises are important. Focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also strengthens your heart, lungs, and body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it’s a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Trills and Achievements**
Seeing a talented child win a medal can make anyone emotional. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.
**A. Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I don't have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gym and school. I try to take each training day by day. When I'm very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."
**B. Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great potential from a young age. Some parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself. People say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was shy and hid behind me, but now she's met people worldwide and gained confidence."
**C. Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love show-jumping events, they are exciting and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. My goal this year is to join the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
**D. Sarah's Mother**  
"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."
**E. Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around. I'm not worried about being proud; I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like embarrassment."
**F. Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to hold her back because she's special. If she has this gift, let her reach her potential."

'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every ten years, people in Europe grow about one centimeter taller on average. More and more tall people are being born each year. This doesn't mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to how we were as cavemen. We are now losing the effects of many years of poor diet, which is having a big impact. 'We are starting to reach our true potential,' says Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived 40,000 years ago.' For most of history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. About 9,000 years ago, farming began, which changed everything. Most green areas were taken over by farmers, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give us more than half of our calories. This poor diet has hurt our health and bodies. Over time, we have eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought a blessing, was actually bad for health, some say. Still, farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. Most people on this diet were poorly nourished, but this is only now being addressed, even in rich countries. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets becoming like our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has problems. People are taller, but beds are still 190 cm long, as they have been since 1860. Leg-room in planes and trains seems to have gotten smaller, and clothing companies have to change their products. The question is: how tall will we get? We can't grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University says it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. But scientists say that while individuals are getting taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were rounder and taller to keep warm. Since the climate warmed, we have become thinner and smaller, even with good food. As the planet heats up, we might shrink more. So, global warming could stop us from growing taller.'

'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV life, but many people don't understand them. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Some people think studio audiences are not very important. I've heard that even TV workers don't respect them much. I thought studio audiences were just people wanting a little fame. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all backgrounds and jobs. TV shows try to get different people for different shows. Some of us who like watching TV at home don't understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in an uncomfortable studio to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. Why did she come? She wanted a chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was 'a friend gave me a ticket'. Few of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH - and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte liked feeling part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.'

**Bruce**  
I don't like places that are completely wild. I like places where people have made a mark. It's the same when I travel to other countries. I like pretty villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Riding my bike was a way to escape school. I loved exploring the lonely hilltops, the safe valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. That was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by people who love trains. I always travel first class because it doesn't cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery is not amazing. The train moves across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when our small train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers can see people doing everyday things, like making tea or doing the dishes. I see myself through their eyes, a woman in a tiny train, looking into other people's homes. It's the normal landscape that I like. Just fields, sheep, and a faraway grey sea. It makes me look closer to find something that surprises me.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so not many people come here. A few brave surfers visit, but most people come to enjoy the beauty of the sea. The coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast that you can combine with trips inland through beautiful, damp valleys full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering places with a family who owns some property in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a landscape of wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there and not many visitors either. It's a hidden place, empty and far away, and I like the feeling of space. I found the area by accident when I was a student, and since then I've visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he's growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted pure peace and to reconnect with my English roots and feel at home. I grew up in what is now called Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we would never ride past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the place of my dreams. It's a magical, hidden, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: A Day with Animals
We are a family that loves animals and enjoys having them around. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She was excited because she found a pine snake and asked if we could keep it. I said yes, but only for one night. We have a special tank for animals we find, so we can look at them and learn about them from our natural history book.
I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting for help. I ran to their room and saw our cat, Domino, with a white mouse in his mouth. The mouse was a gift for Mother's Day. Domino was running around the room, trying to find a place to enjoy his catch, while the kids were waving their arms to stop him. I tried to help but tripped and fell on the floor. Then I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank.
The room was chaotic with the cat, mouse, kids, and the snake all moving around. The dog was barking too. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and came back to the room. I managed to catch Domino by the tail and saved the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived a long life.
Feeling confident, I tried to catch the snake. It was not easy, but I sat on the floor and slowly calmed the snake. Eventually, I picked it up and took it to the garden. I hoped it would go to the garden shed, but when I let go, the snake wrapped around my shoulders like a scarf. My eldest child, DJ, said, "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."
We all helped the snake move towards the shed. It slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!" We all agreed.

'Write me a letter! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old way of writing letters might disappear. But for me, getting a letter is special. There is the excitement when it arrives, the happiness of seeing who sent it, and the joy of reading it. I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote a letter every week, and so did my mother. Sometimes my father wrote too, and his long, funny letters were always a joy to receive. Most letters from home talked about everyday things happening with my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters most. I also got letters from my boyfriends. When I was young, I often had boyfriends who were away for work or study, so we stayed in touch by writing letters. Writing letters seemed to make our relationships better. I found it easier to express myself in writing than in talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's even better to get a year's worth of news! It's even more exciting when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, someone I trained with over 20 years ago. I also have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's a lady who writes to me from France. We started talking in a restaurant on the way home from a holiday. My husband took her photo, and I asked for her address. If she hadn't replied, we wouldn't have this friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French (she doesn't speak English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that a friendship could last so long through letters. The local newspaper even wrote about it on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

Title: Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art
In the French Alps, there is a special place called Mont Bego. Here, you can find 36,000 ancient pictures carved into rocks. These pictures are very old, about 4,000 years, and show cows with horns, fields, and gods and goddesses. This place was once used for prayer and worship. 
However, these important pictures are being damaged by careless tourists. People are writing graffiti on them, stepping on them, and even taking pieces home as souvenirs. Some tourists rub the drawings to make them clearer for photos, which harms the art. Others scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks.
Experts are worried about how to protect these drawings. Jean Clottes, an expert on rock art, says that if the damage continues, the drawings might disappear in 50 years. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the best way to save the site is to stop people from visiting, except on guided tours. But Clottes disagrees, saying this would upset local people.
David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He suggests letting people visit but admits it's hard to stop them from causing damage. He thinks charging a fee might help, but there is no government money to pay for guards.
Annie Echassoux, another researcher, is worried because tourists can now reach the site more easily by hiring vehicles. She believes the area should be roped off and guides provided. She insists that money must be found to protect the site, as it is a historic place. If nothing is done, future generations might lose these ancient drawings.

Shopping with Children
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says her children want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't buy all these things and feels bad if she gives in to their demands. She also feels guilty for saying no all the time. She tries not to take them shopping, but then worries they won't learn how to make choices.
Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a shopping trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and they find it hard to believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when ads make products look so good.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and feel bad when they have to say no to their children.
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, the goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something, even if they can't say it directly.
Some parents find it stressful to decide which of their children's requests to agree to. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads, so they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says he doesn't buy sweets for his son because they are unhealthy, but he buys treats for himself. He says it's normal for children to want nice things, but he still gets annoyed by their demands. His decisions depend on his mood.
Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Even if parents spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands might attract more customers.

'Climbing Walls In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, you can climb anywhere, indoors or outdoors. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham's National Indoor Arena, people watch as French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by two fingers on a climbing wall. This arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, and both events have something in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs with good climbing angles. In winter, they either climbed in cold weather, walked, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, climbers needed to stay fit. When cliffs were not usable, they used brick or stone buildings to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom. Soon, sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges. Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He used natural rock set in concrete blocks for the wall. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had problems. These walls were only vertical, unlike real cliffs with overhangs and angled rocks. Also, once built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored with the same holds. In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a material shaped like real cliff holds. These could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls, but steel frames could be set up anywhere. This system allowed climbers to have new holds all the time.'

'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky.' Acting is indeed a risky career because there are more actors than jobs available. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, but others might support you. Everyone will give different advice. Becoming an actor is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your decision and reaching your goal. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee you will succeed. Success depends on luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and glamorous, with the chance of earning a lot. People often ask what talent is. I think talent is natural skill plus imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. Talent also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to act. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They understand their skills and techniques but know they are only as good as their current job. Fame can be temporary. Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs. Then you get an audition, but you might not get the part. Actors often don't talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, rejection is possible from the first time you try for a role. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. If you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**
We are excited to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.
**A. Delia Smith**
When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple and expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes. The book has been updated recently and is perfect for anyone who wants just one cookbook.
**B. Raymond Blanc**
Raymond Blanc became a top chef and owner of a famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, *Blanc Mange*, goes with his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by showing how ingredients work together. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book has over 80 amazing recipes and explains why some dishes might not turn out well. It also introduces basic food chemistry. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows how good he is at it.
**C. Le Cordon Bleu**
Le Cordon Bleu is known for the best in classical French cooking. For 100 years, this famous cooking school has trained students to cook perfectly.
