To celebrate its anniversary, they released the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, featuring 100 respected recipes. The recipes are classics but still feel fresh. The school has moved away from rich, creamy sauces to healthier options. The book starts with kitchen basics and includes sections on Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from around the world share their famous recipes and secrets.
**D. Nigel Slater**
Fast food? No way! Many think good food takes a long time to cook, but Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, disagrees. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to get a pizza delivered. He has written two successful books before, and this new one has over 200 recipes from around the world. Each recipe can be ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and enjoyable way, proving that fast food can also be great food. Try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring and not fun anymore. He didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but he lost his job unexpectedly. He didn't get much money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. His big chance came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat by mail order. He is happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works 80 to 90 hours a week and sells a product.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him, and he was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work for money. Ron and his family moved to the north of England, where they didn't know anyone. They left their friends, but many friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were long. She didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she never did. She keeps busy with deadlines and fashion collections. She feels happier and less stressed now. She misses socializing with colleagues but loves being responsible for her product. If something goes wrong, it's her responsibility.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started in financial markets at 22, making deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he resigned and traveled for a year. During that time, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took massage courses. He got part-time work at the Life Centre and has no regrets. Now, he feels in control and has peace of mind.

Title: A Childhood Game Becomes a Business
Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are turning a childhood game into a successful business. They live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and love playing an old game called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. The family played it often, especially on weekends and holidays, and had a lot of fun.
When the family moved to New Mexico, they continued playing pichenotte. The game was new to people in the southern USA, and visitors were curious about it. Three years ago, Dave noticed their old game board was damaged, so he made a new one. It was so nice that a relative and a friend wanted one too.
To see if more people were interested, the brothers took the game to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people were unsure about playing, but once they tried it, they loved it. Dave found out that pichenotte is similar to a game from India called 'carroms'. It was adapted in Britain as 'squails' and brought to Canada by British immigrants. In Quebec, it became known as pichenotte.
Pichenotte is a game of skill for two to four players. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks', which they flick across a board with their fingers. The goal is to get the pucks into a small hole for 20 points. There are also rings worth 15, 10, and 5 points, and small posts that make it harder. A game usually lasts two minutes.
Seeing how popular the game was, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. The game became so popular that championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. The boards sold quickly, so the brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and costs $595 on their website.
There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope their business will grow. They dream of one day replacing their workshop with a luxury car. Until then, they enjoy playing the game that might make them rich.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you first come to the Model Village, it's hard to believe that a few years ago, this place was just empty land, covered with wild plants. People thought it was useless land. But one man, with the help of his wife, worked hard to turn it into the beautiful place you see today. They moved a lot of soil and clay to change the flat land into the nice landscape you see now. Machines like bulldozers helped, but there was also a lot of hard work by hand. After shaping the land, they brought in about 1,000 tonnes of good soil to make the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens.
Many trees and bushes were planted in the Model Village. They had to choose plants that could live in the salty air near the sea and survive the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some came from far places like Canada and New Zealand.
Colin Sims thought of the whole village, and he made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting from when the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastics to last in all weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how materials would last in changing weather, but soon he became an expert too.
You will see that the models are all made to the same scale, and even the smallest details are carefully done. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and known for its high quality. The techniques used here are now used in other model villages in England and are even taught in some schools.
All the model buildings show traditional British architecture but are not exact copies of real places. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. It looks like manor houses found in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest part of the village.
Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; a small mistake can mean hours of repair work for us. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. 
To make your visit more fun, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press them to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us make the village more interesting. We also want to know if any models are not as good as the others, so we can fix them. We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC was created to handle such issues. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. Do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where she expected privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. It is surprising that the PCC did not investigate on its own. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, did not make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other unfair stories? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. These decisions would be reported by other newspapers and on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as they would not make money by hiding and taking pictures of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC watch over all British newspapers and magazines? There is also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story they want to keep secret, and they know it might come out if they complain. In this way, even the PCC might seem like an enemy. A British comedian also suffered when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, or later, when his family was photographed on holiday. He was afraid the newspaper, News of the World, would show the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', saying it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many people give advice to students who are leaving college and starting their first job. This article is about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job after a few weeks. We are focusing on those who are ready to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for next? It depends on your long-term goals. Do you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to a higher position, or change to a different field? Whatever you choose, pick your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. It should also help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are ready to focus on your career. 
Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a great first job because the people were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her computer skills. But there was no chance to move up. So, she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette is a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. In two and a half years, Juliette has grown a lot in her job. Her boss wanted to help her develop from the start. Her job title is the same, but her duties have changed. She started with typing and phone work and now handles most of the letters and budgets. She also answers questions from company leaders and people who want to start their own business. Brenda includes Juliette in all her work and gives her special projects and events to organize.

Title: How to Become Confident
Confident people might seem like they were always confident, but many have learned this skill. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
A. Jenny
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At 25, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous but did well, and someone suggested I take a university course. I was scared on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school changed my life and helped me become more confident.
B. Michaela
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and acted too aggressive at first, thinking that's how confident people behave. But I learned that confidence means believing in yourself. If work is too much, I don't feel bad about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something hard, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to overcome it.
C. Lisa
People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. In TV, looking confident is important. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets nervous, and we feel better when talking to friendly people. My mom once told me, "Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves." This advice helps me. You gain confidence by facing your fears. I was nervous for my driving test but passed, and now I feel less scared.
D. Barbara
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but it took time to build. By doing my job and learning from mistakes, I became more confident. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me, and that's okay. You should like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses that boost my confidence. Setting small goals helps me see my progress, instead of aiming too high and achieving nothing.
E. Kim
After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak in meetings. Eventually, I found the courage to share my thoughts. When I started in politics, I was nervous about speaking in public. I told myself, "People do this every day, so you can too." Writing notes helped me feel more secure. Everyone feels nervous about public speaking. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He showed me a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat next to them under the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held the kites, and a line of competitors waited for the start. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying skill. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them needs real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how it's done.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help fix his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur into the mountains with thick rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my eye. It pointed to a path into the forest and said: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' Before starting, I didn't know that most of the path was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tented kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects under my thin mattress. The night was very dark, full of sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and made noises. In the morning, there was a great view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning hit the treetops. Soon, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the heavy rain. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kind people.'

**What kind of shopper are you?**
Everyone goes shopping, even if they love it or hate it. But people shop in different ways. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ...
**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I love shopping! I can't stop spending money. When I have money, I go shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs without buying something. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We are both addicted to shopping!
**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I don't like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all like different things. I don't often spend money on myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and don't tell my husband the real price. The real price always seems too high.
**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for things I really need. I don't like shopping and only go when I must. When I shop, I know exactly what I want and won't buy anything else. I find shopping tiring and would rather do something else.
**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around shops sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and shop quickly. I do have some clothes I bought by mistake, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes mistakes!
**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't like shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want, and nobody helps me. The shops are too noisy and messy, and I find it very stressful. Luckily, I don't have to shop for clothes often because most of my clothes are gifts. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish quickly.
**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I'll buy it.
**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I'm a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don't buy a lot. I usually know what I want and don't spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I often feel worse because I spent too much money!
**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'm a careful shopper. I usually know what I want before I go, and I don't buy things right away. I like to check other shops to find a better deal, so I take a long time.
**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I'm not a fan of shopping. Maybe because I work in the city center, shops don't interest me anymore. When I have to shop, I do it quickly and don't try clothes on because it's too much trouble. Sometimes the clothes I buy don't fit, but I don't mind. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping.
